revision.comment: Inclusion of Quenya mode Tengwar alongside Quenya written in the Latin alphabet.
revision.text:
Quenya has 3 types of adjectives depending on their final letter: * adjectives in {{Tengwar|\`C}} -'''a''': ::{{Tengwar|`Cj1E}} '''alta''' "big" ::{{Tengwar|aY65#}} '''corna''' "round" ::{{Tengwar|j#6aD}} '''larca''' "swift, rapid" ::{{Tengwar|7lDaD}} '''raica''' "bent" ::{{Tengwar|eD7R`C}} '''farëa''' "enough" * adjectives in {{Tengwar|\`V}} -'''ë''': ::{{Tengwar|j.FaR}} '''leucë''' "sick" ::{{Tengwar|5%v$}} '''ninquë''' "white" ::{{Tengwar|aD65$}} '''carnë''' "red" * adjectives in {{Tengwar|\5}} -'''n'''; most end in {{Tengwar|\`B5}} -'''in''' but some in {{Tengwar|\`V5}} -'''en''': ::{{Tengwar|t#7T5}} '''marin''' "ripe" ::{{Tengwar|zDj%5}} '''qualin''' "dead" ::{{Tengwar|qR7R5}} '''peren''' "patient" Adjectives are mostly placed in front of the noun to which they belong: ::{{Tengwar|j#6aD 8~B7R}} '''larca sírë''' "a rapid river" ::{{Tengwar|`B 5%v$ eD5Ì#}} '''i ninquë fanya''' "the white cloud" It is emphasized by putting it after its noun: ::{{Tengwar|t#j°$ 7lDaD}} '''mallë raica''' "a bent (and not straight) road" With a proper noun adjectives are always put behind the noun: ::{{Tengwar|`Vj$2%j yY7Y2#}} '''Elendil Voronda''' "Elendil (the) Faithful, Faithful Elendil" Adjectives can also be used predicatively with the verb '''ná''': ::{{Tengwar|`B qE6t# 5~C aD65$}} '''i parma ná carnë''' "the book is red" In such short sentences {{Tengwar|5~C}} '''ná''' or {{Tengwar|5#6}} '''nar''' is often omitted: ::{{Tengwar|`B qE6t# aD65$}} '''i parma carnë''' "the book is red" ==Plural== Adjectives have only one plural form; it is used whenever the noun it belongs to is not singular (so dual, plural and partitive plural make no difference for the adjective): ::{{Tengwar|aD65% qE6t#6}} '''carni parmar''' "red books" ::{{Tengwar|aD65% qE6t#1}} '''carni parmat''' "a pair of red books" ::{{Tengwar|aD65% qE6t#j%}} '''carni parmali''' "some red books" Predicatively used adjectives are in the plural whenever the subject refers to more than one person or thing: ::{{Tengwar|`B aG7ÎE6 5#6 5%v%}} '''i ciryar nar ninqui''' "the ships are white" ::{{Tengwar|`B `C7E6 `C6 `B 1~C7T 5#6 `Cj1R}} '''i aran ar i tári nar altë''' "the king and queen are big" '''''Formation of the plural''''': * adjectives in {{Tengwar|\`C}} -'''a''' but not in {{Tengwar|\`V`C}} -'''ëa''': ::{{Tengwar|`Cj1E}} '''alta''' → {{Tengwar|`Cj1R}} '''altë''' "big" ::{{Tengwar|aY65#}} '''corna''' → {{Tengwar|aY65$}} '''cornë''' "round" ::{{Tengwar|7lDaD}} '''raica''' → {{Tengwar|7lDaR}} '''raicë''' "bent" * adjectives in {{Tengwar|\`V`C}} -'''ëa''': ::{{Tengwar|eD7R`C}} '''farëa''' → {{Tengwar|eD7T`V}} '''farië''' "enough" ::{{Tengwar|j.D7R`C}} '''laurëa''' → {{Tengwar|j.D7T`V}} '''laurië''' "golden" * adjectives in {{Tengwar|\`V}} -'''ë''': ::{{Tengwar|j.FaR}} '''leucë''' → {{Tengwar|j.FaG}} '''leuci''' "sick" ::{{Tengwar|5%v$}} '''ninquë''' → {{Tengwar|5%v%}} '''ninqui''' "white" * adjectives in {{Tengwar|\5}} -'''n''' have two possible forms: ::{{Tengwar|t#7T5}} '''marin''' → {{Tengwar|t#7T5% - t#7T2%}} '''marini'''/'''marindi''' "ripe" ::{{Tengwar|zDj%5}} '''qualin''' → {{Tengwar|zDj%5% - zDj%2%}} '''qualini'''/'''qualindi''' "dead" ::{{Tengwar|qR7R5}} '''peren''' → {{Tengwar|qR7R5% - qR7R2%}} '''pereni'''/'''perendi''' "patient" One adjective is irregular: ::{{Tengwar|tlD1R}} '''maitë''' → {{Tengwar|tlDiG}} '''maisi''' "handy" ==Inflected adjectives== In Quenya there are only 2 occurrences in which the adjectives are inflected: * when the adjective is used as a noun * when the adjective immediately follows its noun In all other places an adjective only has 2 forms: singular and plural (see above). Examples and paradigms can be found on a separate page: [[../Inflected adjectives/]]. ==Comparative== Quenya uses two different comparatives: relative and absolute. ===relative comparison=== When we use an adjective in a relative comparison, it is preceded by {{Tengwar|j~C}} '''lá''' but its form doesn’t change: ::{{Tengwar|`N7Yt$ 5~C 9Dj°# j~C t#2^8}} '''Oromë ná halla lá Mandos''' "Orome is taller than Mandos" ::{{Tengwar|`C5#6 5~C aDj%t# j~C `BiGj}} '''Anar ná calima lá Isil''' "The sun is brighter than the moon" Note: {{Tengwar|j~C}} '''lá''' is also used to negate a [[../Verbs|verb]], so it can appear with both meanings in one sentence: ::{{Tengwar|j~C aD7Tj´$8 tlDaD j~C t#aGj$7ÎE}} '''lá carilyes maica lá macilerya''' "you don't make it sharper than your sword" If one is unsure of the meaning of which {{Tengwar|j~C}} '''lá''' is being used, simply identify the following word to determine the meaning: :: {{Tengwar|j~C}} '''lá''' followed by "noun": relative comparison :: {{Tengwar|j~C}} '''lá''' followed by "verb": verb negation ===absolute comparison=== If on the other hand the comparison is used absolutively, we have a special ending {{Tengwar|\m#}} –'''lda''': ::{{Tengwar|`N7Yt$ 5~C 9Dj°#m#}} '''Oromë ná hallalda''' "Orome is longer" So these comparatives are always adjectives on {{Tengwar|\`C}} –'''a''' and follow the rules of these adjectives: ::{{Tengwar|jlDzDm$ qRj$7T}} '''laiqualdë peleri''' "greener fields" To apply the ending to adjectives on {{Tengwar|\`V}} –'''ë''' we use their I-stem: ::{{Tengwar|5%v$}} '''ninquë''' "white" → {{Tengwar|5%v%m#}} '''ninquilda''' and adjectives on {{Tengwar|\`B5 - \`V5}} –'''in'''/-'''en''' get the ending {{Tengwar|\`Bm#}} –'''ilda''': ::{{Tengwar|t$j%5}} '''melin''' "dear" → {{Tengwar|t$j%5%m#}} '''melinilda''' Finally, a few are irregular: ::{{Tengwar|t~C7E - t#5$}} '''mára'''/'''manë''' "good" → {{Tengwar|t#m#}} '''malda''' "better" ::{{Tengwar|yE5Ì#}} '''vanya''' "beautiful, fair" → {{Tengwar|yEm#}} '''valda''' "more beatiful, fairer" ::{{Tengwar|`MjaD}} '''ulca''' "bad" → {{Tengwar|`Mm#}} '''ulda''' "worse" ::{{Tengwar|elDaD}} '''faica''' "bad" → {{Tengwar|eRm#}} '''felda''' "worse" ::{{Tengwar|j%w#}} '''limba''' "many" → {{Tengwar|j%m#}} '''lilda''' "more" ::{{Tengwar|`Nj´#}} '''olya''' "much" → {{Tengwar|`Nm#}} '''olda''' "more" and the diminutive: ::{{Tengwar|t#f#}} '''manca''' "few" → {{Tengwar|t%1E+}} '''mitsa''' "less" ==Superlative== The superlative is formed by applying the prefix {{Tengwar|`C5\}} '''an'''- to the adjective: ::{{Tengwar|aDj%t#}} '''calima''' "clear" → {{Tengwar|`Cf#j%t#}} '''ancalima''' "clearest" ::{{Tengwar|yT5Ì#}} '''vinya''' "new" → {{Tengwar|`C5yT5Ì#}} '''anvinya''' "newest" This prefix cannot be applied to every adjective as otherwise unallowed consonant clusters could appear (see [[../Phonology/]]).
It can be prefixed to adjectives beginning in: a vowel, '''c'''-, '''n'''-, '''qu'''-, '''t'''-, '''v'''-, '''w'''-, '''y'''-, '''f'''-. some other consonants can get the prefix {{Tengwar|`C5#\}} '''ana'''-: ::{{Tengwar|`Cj1E}} '''alta''' "big" → {{Tengwar|`C5#j1E}} '''analta''' "biggest" ::{{Tengwar|5%2$}} '''nindë''' "fragile" → {{Tengwar|`C5:%2$}} '''annindë''' "most fragile" ::{{Tengwar|zD4#}} '''quanta''' "full" → {{Tengwar|`Cv#4#}} '''anquanta''' "fullest" ::{{Tengwar|nTjnE}} '''wilwa''' "vague" → {{Tengwar|`C5nTjnE}} '''anwilwa''' "vaguest" ::{{Tengwar|hÍRjnE}} '''yelwa''' "loathsome" → {{Tengwar|`C5Ì$jnE}} '''anyelwa''' "most loathsome" ::{{Tengwar|eU7T5}} '''furin''' "hidden" → {{Tengwar|`C5eU7T5}} '''anfurin''' "most hidden" ::{{Tengwar|9Dj°#}} '''halla''' "long" → {{Tengwar|`C5#dEj°#}} '''anahalla''' "longest" When an adjective begins in {{Tengwar|q\}} '''p'''- the prefix becomes {{Tengwar|`Ct\}} '''am'''-: ::{{Tengwar|qT1ÎE}} '''pitya''' "small, little" → {{Tengwar|`Cr%1ÎE}} '''ampitya''' "smallest" Before '''l'''-, '''m'''-, '''r'''-, '''s'''- the '''n''' of '''an'''- changes into an double consonant: ::{{Tengwar|jlDaD}} '''lauca''' "warm" → {{Tengwar|`Cj°lDaD}} '''allauca''' "warmest" ::{{Tengwar|7Ts#}} '''ringa''' "cold" → {{Tengwar|`C7;Ts#}} '''arringa''' "coldest" ::{{Tengwar|iDuE}} '''sarda''' "hard" → {{Tengwar|`C,DuE}} '''assarda''' "hardest" ::{{Tengwar|t#7T5}} '''marin''' "ripe" → {{Tengwar|`C5:#7T5}} '''ammarin''' "ripest" But when we look at the historical development of Quenya, a large group of adjectives must have 'historical' irregularities, e.g. ::{{Tengwar|yE5Ì#}} '''vanya''' "beautiful" → {{Tengwar|`Cw#5Ì#}} '''ambanya''' "most beautiful" We will look at these on a separate page: [[../Old-Elvish influences|historical superlatives]]. ---- >> [[Neo-Quenya]] >> [[../Adjectives/]] {{BookCat}}

==Usage== ===adjectives used as a noun=== We translate this in English by using the word "one" with the adjective: ::{{Tengwar|jlDaD}} '''laica''' "a keen one";    {{Tengwar|`B jlDaD}} '''i laica''' "the keen one" ::{{Tengwar|aD65$}} '''carnë''' "a red one";    {{Tengwar|`B aD65$}} '''i carnë''' "the red one" ::{{Tengwar|cE7T5}} '''hwarin''' "a crooked one   {{Tengwar|`B cE7T5}} '''i hwarin''' "the crooked one" In this case the adjective is inflected with the noun endings: ::{{Tengwar|jlDaD6}} '''laicar''' "keen ones";   {{Tengwar|aD65%}} '''carni''' "red ones";   {{Tengwar|cE7T2%}} '''hwarindi''' "crooked ones" Dual and partitive plural are also possible: ::{{Tengwar|jlDaD1}} '''laicat''' "a pair of keen ones"   {{Tengwar|aD65%1}} '''carnit''' "a pair of red ones";   {{Tengwar|`B cE7T2&}} '''i hwarindu''' "both crooked ones" ::{{Tengwar|jlDaDj%}} '''laicali''' "some keen ones";   {{Tengwar|aD65%j%}} '''carnili''' "some red ones";   {{Tengwar|cE7T2$j%}} '''hwarindeli ''' "some crooked ones" These nouns can of course take all case endings, e.g. ::{{Tengwar|jlDaD7Y5}} '''laicaron''' (genitive plural);   {{Tengwar|aD65%j°^}} '''carnillo''' (ablative singular);   {{Tengwar|`B cE7T2&5}} '''i hwarindun''' (dative dual) ... ===adjectives following the noun=== When the adjective is put behind its noun, the rule of the last declinable word applies. This means that the adjective takes the case endings and the noun loses them: ::{{Tengwar|aY`C aD65%5:#}} '''coa carninna''' "to a red house" (allative) ::{{Tengwar|aY`C aD65%j°^}} '''coa carnillo''' "from a red house" (ablative) In the plural the adjective has the plural case-endings and the noun is in the nominative plural: ::{{Tengwar|aY`C6 aD65%5:#6}} '''coar carninnar''' "to red houses" (allative) In the dual the adjective has the dual case-endings and the noun is in the nominative dual: ::{{Tengwar|aU`C1 aD65%j1Y}} '''coat carnilto''' "from a pair of red houses" (ablative) Note: adjectives only have t-duals even if they contain a d- or t-sound: ::{{Tengwar|`B `Cm& 1.GaD1R+}} '''i aldu tiucatsë''' "in both thick trees" (locative) The other types of words that are inflected in this way are: * participles when they follow the noun (see [[../Verbal forms/]]) * [[../Pronouns|demonstrative pronouns]] * titles also always follow the noun, so it is also the title and not the noun itself that is inflected: ::{{Tengwar|`Vj$2%j yY7Y2#}} '''Elendil Voronda''' "Elendil the Faithful" ::{{Tengwar|`Vj$2%j yY7Y2#5}} '''Elendil Vorondan''' "to Elendil the Faithful" (dative) ::{{Tengwar|`Vj$2%j yY7Y2#j°^}} '''Elendil Vorondallo''' "from Elendil the Faithful" (ablative) But there are two cases in which this rule isn't followed: * When the noun is in the [[../Nouns|partitive plural]], the case ending remains with the noun and the adjective has its original (plural) form: ::{{Tengwar|aU`Cj%,R aD65%}} '''coalissë carni''' "in some red houses" (locative) * The adjectives on {{Tengwar|\`V`C}} –'''ëa''' only have a plural form and no other cases so the ending remains with the noun: ::{{Tengwar|aY`C5:# j.D7R`C}} '''coanna laurëa''' "to a golden house" (allative) ::{{Tengwar|aY`C5:#6 j.D7T`V}} '''coannar laurië''' "to golden houses" (allative) ==Paradigms== A few remarks: * The forms of the plural can only be used when the adjective follows the noun, not when it is used as a noun. But in that case it follows the ordinary rules of [[../Declension Paradigms]]. * Adjectives on {{Tengwar|\`V`C}} -'''ëa''' cannot be inflected so they aren't included in these tables. They can be used as nouns but in that case they are inflected like the nouns {{Tengwar|`Cr#}} '''ampa''' "hook" or {{Tengwar|`Cm#}} '''alda''' "tree". * The partitive plural can only be used when the adjective is used as a noun so it isn't included in the table. Adjectives on {{Tengwar|\`C}} -'''a''' (but not {{Tengwar|\`V`C}} -'''ëa''') are inflected as follows ({{Tengwar|`C2#}} '''anda''' "long"):
singular plural dual
nominative {{Tengwar|`C2#}}
anda		 {{Tengwar|`C2$}}
andë		 {{Tengwar|`C2#1}}
andat
genitive {{Tengwar|`C2^}}

andato
possessive {{Tengwar|`C2#yE}}

Adjectives on -'''ë''' are inflected as follows ('''ninquë''' "white"):
singular plural dual
nominative {{Tengwar|5%v$}}

ninquit

Adjectives on -'''n''' are inflected as follows ('''melin''' "dear"):
singular plural dual

revision.comment: Inclusion of Quenya mode Tengwar alongside Quenya written in the Latin alphabet.
revision.text:
We have met the prefix <small>{{Tengwar|`C5\}}</small> '''an'''- for the superlative. We also said that this prefix can change under the influence of the beginning consonant of the adjective. But in all these cases the changes are in the prefix <small>{{Tengwar|`C5\}}</small> '''an'''- itself, the original adjective is not influenced.
With the Old-Elvish influences however we are getting the original forms of the adjectives back in the superlative. Most of these forms are analoguous to the changes in the [[../Perfect Tense|perfect tense]].
=== Adjectives in '''mb'''/'''nd'''/'''ng''' === Let’s first look at adjectives that started with the combinations <small>{{Tengwar|w\}}</small> '''mb'''-, <small>{{Tengwar|2\}}</small> '''nd'''- and <small>{{Tengwar|s\}}</small> '''ng'''- in Old-Elvish: * <small>{{Tengwar|w\}}</small> '''mb'''-: ::<small>{{Tengwar|t#61E}}</small> '''marta''' "fated" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw#61E}}</small> '''ambarta''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|t$7ÎE}}</small> '''merya''' "festive" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw$7ÎE}}</small> '''amberya''' * <small>{{Tengwar|2\}}</small> '''nd'''-: ::<small>{{Tengwar|5&j°#}}</small> '''nulla''' "obscure" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C2&j°#}}</small> '''andulla''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|5~Mt$5Ì#}}</small> '''númenya''' "western" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C2~Mt$5Ì#}}</small> '''andúmenya''' * <small>{{Tengwar|s\}}</small> '''ng'''-: ::<small>{{Tengwar|g~Nj# \ 5~Nj#}}</small> '''nóla''' "learned" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cs~Nj#}}</small> '''angóla''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|b#jaD}}</small> '''nwalca''' "cruel" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cx#jaD}}</small> '''angwalca'''
=== Adjectives in '''d''' === Also an <small>{{Tengwar|j\}}</small> '''l'''- that has evolved from '''d'''- has such influences: ::<small>{{Tengwar|jlD7E}}</small> '''laira''' "shady" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C2lD7E}}</small> '''andaira''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|j~C7E}}</small> '''lára''' "flat" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C2~C7E}}</small> '''andára''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|j~Nt$`C}}</small> '''lómëa''' "gloomy" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C2~Nt$`C}}</small> '''andómëa''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|j~N7E}}</small> '''lóra''' "dark" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C2~N7E}}</small> '''andóra''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|j&t5#}}</small> '''lumna''' "oppressive" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C2&t5#}}</small> '''andumna'''
=== Adjectives in '''b'''/'''w''' === A large number of adjectives that begin in <small>{{Tengwar|y\}}</small> '''v'''- in Neo-Quenya, had a '''b'''- in Old-Elvish. Here we find that <small>{{Tengwar|`C5}}</small> '''an''' + <small>{{Tengwar|y}}</small> '''v''' gives rise to the original <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw\}}</small> '''amb'''-: ::<small>{{Tengwar|yE5ÌE}}</small> '''vanya''' "beautiful" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw#5Ì#}}</small> '''ambanya''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yEjlD5#}}</small> '''valaina''' "divine" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw#jlD5#}}</small> '''ambalaina''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yEj´#}}</small> '''valya''' "powerful" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw#j´#}}</small> '''ambalya''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yE5%t#}}</small> '''vanima''' "fair" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw#5%t#}}</small> '''ambanima''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yE65#}}</small> '''varna''' "safe" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw#65#}}</small> '''ambarna''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yE65$}}</small> '''varnë''' "brown" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw$65$}}</small> '''ambarnë''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yR6aD}}</small> '''verca''' "wild" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw$6aD}}</small> '''amberca''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yR7ÎE}}</small> '''verya''' "bold" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw$7ÎE}}</small> '''amberya''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yY7Tt#}}</small> '''vorima''' "continual" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw^7Tt#}}</small> '''amborima''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yY7Y5nE}}</small> '''voronwa''' "enduring" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw^7Y5nE}}</small> '''amboronwa'''
In some the '''v'''- evolved from '''w'''-: ::<small>{{Tengwar|y~C7E}}</small> '''vára''' "dirty" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C5n~C7E}}</small> '''anwára''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yR`C}}</small> '''vëa''' "manly" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C5nR`C}}</small> '''anwëa''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|y~V7E}}</small> '''véra''' "personal" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C5n~V7E}}</small> '''anwéra''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|yT2$}}</small> '''vindë''' "blue-grey" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C5nT2$}}</small> '''anwindë'''
The adjective '''wenya''' "green, fresh" has evolved from <small>{{Tengwar|}}</small> '''''gwen''''', so it has following superlative: ::<small>{{Tengwar|nR5Ì#}}</small> '''wenya''' "green, fresh" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cx$5Ì#}}</small> '''angwenya'''
----
