== WorldView : Conflict Object ==
If you discover an object and it comes up with Conflict_Object, then you search and search and search and find no other object with the same name or ip address do the following:
Using Worldview Open Details of the Conflict_Object Select the status tab Deselect the 'Hidden' checkbox Click OK Reclassify the object to the correct class
If you just reclassify without fixing the checkbox then unispace appears in the Unplace objects container and the Operating system object has no icon in the subnet container. also, reclassifying and ''then'' unchecking the hidden checkbox does not work.
[[Category:CA Unicenter NSM Textbook]]

Neo-Quenya has 3 types of verbs. In the word list they can be recognized by the final letter of the stem: *Primitive verbs, ending on a consonant *A-verbs *U-verbs Some [[../Special Verbs|special verbs]] can be found on a separate page. A Quenya verb has 5 tenses: *Present *Aorist *Past *Perfect *Future The [[../Verbal forms|verbal forms]] (infinitive, participle, gerund) and the [[../Imperative|imperative]] are each discussed in a separate article. ==Endings== Quenya verb conjugation is rather special because it can have subject and object endings, :e.g. {{Tengwar|9.D1E5Ì$j}} '''hautanyel''' can be decomposed as follows: :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E\5Ì$\j}} '''hauta-nyë-l'''. The verb is {{Tengwar|9.D1E\}} '''hauta'''- "stop", the first ending {{Tengwar|\5Ì$}} -'''nyë''' is a subject ending and means "I", the second ending {{Tengwar|\j}} -'''l''' is an object ending and means "you". So the translation is "I stop you". In the form {{Tengwar|9.D1Ej´$5}} '''hautalyen''' object and subject are reversed, so it means "you stop me". When only one ending is present it is always a subject ending: :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E5 = 9.D1E5Ì$}} '''hautan, hautanyë''' both mean "I stop" :* {{Tengwar|9.D1Ej = 9.D1Ej´$}} '''hautal, hautalyë''' both mean "you stop" So let's have a look at the different endings: * 1st person singular: {{Tengwar|\5}} -'''n''' or {{Tengwar|\5Ì$}} -'''nyë''' (both can be used as a subject ending, only {{Tengwar|\5}} -'''n''' as an object ending) * 2nd person singular and plural: {{Tengwar|\j}} -'''l''' or {{Tengwar|\j´$}} -'''lyë''' (both can be used as a subject ending, only {{Tengwar|\j}} -'''l''' as an object ending) * 3rd person plural: {{Tengwar|\1}} -'''t''' or {{Tengwar|\4$}} -'''ntë''' ({{Tengwar|\4$}} -'''ntë''' is always used as a subject ending, and {{Tengwar|\1}} -'''t''' always as an object ending): :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E4$}} '''hautantë''' "they stop" :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E4$5}} '''hautanten''' "they stop me" :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E5Ì$1}} '''hautanyet''' "I stop them", etc. The other 2 persons are more complicated: The 1st person plural has 3 different subject endings and no object endings. So when an object is in the 1st person plural it is always a separate pronoun (see [[../Pronouns/]]). The 3 subject endings are: :{{Tengwar|\jt$}} -'''lmë''': this is called the 'exclusive we', because it is used when the listener is not included in the group that is meant by "we": :* {{Tengwar|9.D1Ejt$}} '''hautalmë''' means "we stop [but not you]" :{{Tengwar|\jyR}} -'''lvë''': this is called the 'inclusive we', because it is used when the listener is also included in the group that is meant by "we": :* {{Tengwar|9.D1EjyR}} '''hautalvë''' means "we stop [including you]" :{{Tengwar|\t:$}} -'''mmë''': this is used when "we" contains exactly 2 people, so it is usually translated as "both of us": :* {{Tengwar|9.D1Et:$}} '''hautammë''' "the two of us stop" The 3rd person singular also has more than one ending: :{{Tengwar|\8}} -'''s''': this ending is used as an object ending or as a subject ending when no object ending is present: :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E5Ì$8}} '''hautanyes''' "I stop him/her/it" :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E8}} '''hautas''' "he/she/it stops" :{{Tengwar|\,F}} -'''sse''': this ending is used as a subject ending when an object ending is present, though also by itself: :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E,Fj}} '''hautassel''' "he/she/it stops you" In the past an ending {{Tengwar|\7ÎR}} -'''rye''' was theorized based on the possessive {{Tengwar|\7ÎD}} '''-rya'''; however this has not yet been attested, and we instead find {{Tengwar|\,F}} '''-sse''' as well as inanimate {{Tengwar|\,D}} '''-ssa'''. However, this is not all: there are also non-pronominal endings that are used when the subject is something other than a pronoun. In this case there can be no object ending, the object is thus always represented by a separate word or pronoun. :The singular non-pronominal form does not have an ending: {{Tengwar|`B `C7E5 9.D1E}} '''i aran hauta''' "the king stops" :The plural non-pronominal ending is {{Tengwar|\6}} -'''r''': {{Tengwar|`B `Vm#6 9.D1E6}} '''i eldar hautar''' "the elves stop" The plural non-pronominal ending is also used when the subject is in the dual or partitive plural: :* {{Tengwar|`B `Vm& 9.D1E6}} '''i eldu hautar''' "both elves stop" :* {{Tengwar|`B `Vm#j% 9.D1E6}} '''eldali hautar''' "some elves stop" In the third person singular there exist two alternative endings for {{Tengwar|\,F\}} -'''sse'''- that can express gender, though these seem to be limited to Qenya of the 1940s and earlier: {{Tengwar|7Y}} -'''ro'''- for a male subject and {{Tengwar|7R}} -'''re'''- for a female subject: :* {{Tengwar|1T7T7Y1}} '''tirirot''' "he sees them" :* {{Tengwar|1T7T7R1}} '''tiriret''' "she sees them" It is interesting to note that in sentences where a free pronoun is present, which serves to emphasise the subject of the sentence, the presence of the free pronoun may allow a verb to stand without the corresponding ending: :{{Tengwar|9.D1Ej´$}} '''hautalyë''' "you (singular) will stop (it)" :{{Tengwar|`Vj´$ 9.D1E}} '''elyë hauta''' "even you (singular) will stop (it)" (without the expected ending -'''lyë''' "you") More about this can be found on the page about [[../Personal pronouns|personal pronouns]]. ==Aorist Tense== The easiest tense is the Aorist as it is formed by the verbal stem from the dictionary and the endings we discussed before. So in fact all forms above are Aorists. It is used as an alternative present tense (see below), and so it isn't a past tense as its Greek namesake. The formation of this tense can be seen in the next table. Only the non-pronominal forms are included as the others can be constructed by replacing the -'''r''' of the plural non-pronominal form with the right pronominal ending. Note that the forms without an ending have a vowel change in the Primitive verbs and the U-stems.
The Aorist Tense
Primitive A-stems U-stems
meaning ''find'' ''stop'' ''snow''
stem {{Tengwar|9G6\}} hir- {{Tengwar|9.D1E\}} hauta- {{Tengwar|5%aU\}} nicu-
singular {{Tengwar|9G7R}}
hirë		 {{Tengwar|9.D1E}} hauta {{Tengwar|5%zF}} niquë
plural {{Tengwar|9G7T6}} hirir {{Tengwar|9.D1E6}} hautar {{Tengwar|5%zT6}} niquir
Note that some verbs have a long vowel in the stem so their Aorists also contain a long vowel: * {{Tengwar|a~M5#\}} '''cúna'''- "bow" → aorist: {{Tengwar|a~M5#}} '''cúna''' * {{Tengwar|8~MhÎE\}} '''súya'''- "breathe" → aorist: {{Tengwar|8~MhÎE}} '''súya''' * {{Tengwar|t~N1E\}} '''móta'''- "labour" → aorist: {{Tengwar|t~N1E}} '''móta''' ==Present Tense== This tense is also called the Continuative tense. The usage and its contrast with the Aorist Tense are explained below. The major principle behind this tense is the central vowel-lengthening. The central vowel is the vowel in the final syllable of a primitive verb, or the vowel in the last syllable but one in an A-stem or U-stem verb. Of course this lengthening can only happen if the syllable isn't long by itself. Following syllables are already long and cannot be lengthened: * a syllable with a diphthong, e.g. {{Tengwar|9.D1E\}} '''hauta'''- "stop" * a syllable with a long vowel, e.g. {{Tengwar|8~MhÎE\}} '''súya'''- "breathe" * a syllable in which the vowel is followed by more than one consonant, e.g. {{Tengwar|9C65#\}} '''harna'''- "wound" Furthermore, the primitive and U-stems get an extra {{Tengwar|\`C}} -'''a''' at the end of the stem and the final -'''a''' of the A-stems changes into {{Tengwar|\`V`C}} -'''ëa'''. So this gives:
The Present Tense with vowel lengthening
Primitive A-stems U-stems
meaning ''find'' ''dig'' ''spread''
stem {{Tengwar|9G6\}} hir- {{Tengwar|aDyE\}} cava- {{Tengwar|qEj&\}} palu-
singular {{Tengwar|9~B7E}} híra {{Tengwar|a~CyR`C}} cávëa {{Tengwar|q~Cj&`C}} pálua
plural {{Tengwar|9~B7E6}} hírar {{Tengwar|a~CyR`C6}} cávëar {{Tengwar|q~Cj&`C6}} páluar
The Present Tense without vowel lengthening
Primitive A-stems U-stems
meaning ''breathe'' ''grumble''
stem {{Tengwar|8~MhÎE\}} súya- {{Tengwar|5&7;U\}} nurru-
singular {{Tengwar|8~MhÎR`C}} súyëa {{Tengwar|5&7;U`C}} nurrua
plural {{Tengwar|8~MhÎR`C6}} súyëar {{Tengwar|5&7;U`C6}} nurruar
There is one verb with an irregular Present Tense: {{Tengwar|1R5\}} '''ten'''- "indicate, show". Its present tense is formed with the stem {{Tengwar|1R`C}} '''tëa'''-: :{{Tengwar|1R`C5}} '''tëan''' "I show", {{Tengwar|1R`C4$}} '''tëantë''' "they show", {{Tengwar|`B 8lD7Y5 1E`C}} '''i sairon tëa''' "the wizard shows", ... Another way of conjugating the present tense affecting certain verbs (coexistent with '''-ëa''') lengthens the form before the derivative suffix, i.e. present {{Tengwar|t~C5#1E}} '''mánata''' and aorist {{Tengwar|t#4#}} '''manta'''. === Usage of Aorist and Present tenses === Most of the time both tenses can be used interchangeably. But there are a few cases in which one of them is clearly preferred: :The Present tense indicates duration, while the Aorist indicates a law or custom: :* {{Tengwar|`B t~Ct# t~C1E iDjzF}} '''i máma máta salquë''' "the sheep is eating grass" :* {{Tengwar|`B t~Ct# t~C1R iDjzF}} '''i máma matë salquë''' "the sheep eats grass" The first sentence means something like "the sheep is at this moment, eating grass" and the second sentence "The sheep eats grass in general". The Aorist can be used to indicate an action in which the moment on which the action is performed is irrelevant: * {{Tengwar|`Vj$5 iGj$}} '''elen silë''' "there shines a star" * {{Tengwar|j#j#}} '''lala''' "someone laughs" The Aorist can indicate sudden change while the Present tense indicates that a condition is true for a certain length of time: * {{Tengwar|`B 5~V6 `N61R`C}} '''i nér ortëa''' "the man is standing" (he stood there and he is still standing) * {{Tengwar|`B 5~V6 `N61E}} '''i nér orta''' "the mans stands" (he was sitting down and gets up) The Aorist can also be used to denote a custom or something recurring: * {{Tengwar|`B `Nd1E6 8~MaE 8~B}} '''i ohtar súca sí''' "the soldier is drinking now" * {{Tengwar|`B `Nd1E6 iUaR `Bj´# .D7R}} '''i ohtar sucë ilya aurë''' "the soldier drinks each day" ==Future Tense== Neo-Quenya has only one future tense, so it is used to indicate both near and distant future: * {{Tengwar|aF5&yE8 `BiGj}} '''cenuvas Isil''' "he shall see the moon/he is going to see the moon" This tense can be recognized by the ending {{Tengwar|\`MyE}} -'''uva'''. The Primitive verbs simply add it, with the A-verbs it replaces the final -'''a''', and with the U-verbs the final -'''u''' changes -'''uva''' into {{Tengwar|\~MyE}} -'''úva''':
The Future Tense
Primitive A-stems U-stems
meaning ''find'' ''stop'' ''wash''
stem hir-
{{Tengwar|9G6\}}		 hauta-
{{Tengwar|9.D1E\}}		 allu-
{{Tengwar|`Cj°&\}}
singular hiruva
{{Tengwar|9G7UyE}}		 hautuva
{{Tengwar|9.D1UyE}}		 allúva
{{Tengwar|`Cj°~MyE}}
plural hiruvar
{{Tengwar|9G7UyE6}}		 hautuvar
{{Tengwar|9.D1UyE6}}		 allúvar
{{Tengwar|`Cj°~MyE6}}
The verb {{Tengwar|zD1\}} '''quat'''- "fill" is irregular as its Future Tense is {{Tengwar|zD4&yE \ zD4&yE6}} '''quantuva'''/'''quantuvar'''. ==Past Tense== The [[../Past Tense|past tense]] has many irregularities, so a separate article is dedicated to it. It is used to denote a past action that still continues or that has finished without consequences. So it can be translated by either a Simple Past or a Present Perfect: * {{Tengwar|e.D1E5$ `CzD `B .D7R}} '''fautanë aqua i aurë''' "it snowed/it was snowing/it has snowed the whole day" ==Perfect Tense== The Perfect Tense is used to express an action that has finished but still has some consequences, so it can be used for the English Present Perfect and Past Perfect: * {{Tengwar|`Ct~C1T`V5}} '''amátien''' "I have eaten" (and I am still not hungry) * {{Tengwar|5~N `Va~V5%`V5Ì$8= `H`C4$8}} '''nó ecénienyes, oantes''' "after I had seen him, he went away" The conjugation of verbs in this tense can be found on a separate page: [[../Perfect Tense/]]. ==Negation of verbs== Neo-Quenya has two ways to negate a sentence: * when the sentence contains a verb without object ending or a modal verb with an [[../Verbal forms|infinitive]], the verb {{Tengwar|`M`C\}} '''ua'''- "not to be" is preferred * in all other cases we use the particle {{Tengwar|j~C}} '''lá''' (Note: '''lá''' is also used with the [[../Adjectives|comparison of adjectives]]). '''''Conjugation of''''' '''ua'''-: :Aorist Tense: {{Tengwar|`M`C}} '''ua''' :* {{Tengwar|`M`C5 = `M`Cj}} uan, ual, ... :Past Tense: {{Tengwar|~M5$}} '''únë''' :* {{Tengwar|~M5$5 = ~M5$j}} únen, únel, ... :Perfect Tense: {{Tengwar|lU`V}} '''uië''' :* {{Tengwar|lU`V5 = lU`Vj}} uien, uiel, ... :Future Tense: {{Tengwar|~MyE}} '''úva''' :* {{Tengwar|~MyE5 = ~MyEj}} úvan, úval, ... To negate a verb we use the corresponding conjugated form of {{Tengwar|`M`C}} '''ua'''- followed by the [[../Verbal forms|infinitive]] of the original verb: * {{Tengwar|aF5%5 `B `Cm#}} '''cenin i alda''' "I see the tree" * {{Tengwar|`M`C5 aF5$ `B `Cm#}} '''uan cenë i alda''' "I don't see the tree" Normally Quenya has the aorist form of '''ua''' followed by the tense-conjugated verb, but in archaic or verse Quenya '''ua''' can be conjugated and the following verb will remain in the aorist: * (Normal / prose) {{Tengwar|`M`C5 t#4$ t~Ct#j´#}} '''uan mantë mámalya''' "I did not eat your sheep" * (Archaic / verse) {{Tengwar|~M5$5 t#1R t~Ct#j´#}} '''únen matë mámalya''' "I did not eat your sheep" With a modal verb, the negation is expressed by two consecutive infinitives: * {{Tengwar|`B 9~B5% qYj%6 aDqR}} '''i híni polir capë''' "the children can jump" * {{Tengwar|`B 9~B5% `M`C6 qYj$ aDqR}} '''i híni uar polë capë''' "the children cannot jump" The verb {{Tengwar|`M`C}} '''ua'''- is also used to negate a sentence with {{Tengwar|5~C}} '''ná''': * {{Tengwar|`B `C7E5 5~C 1.D7E}} '''i aran ná taura''' "the king is mighty" * {{Tengwar|`B `C7E5 `M`C 1.D7E}} '''i aran ua taura''' "the king is not mighty" When a verb has an object ending (and thus also a subject ending) we never use {{Tengwar|`M`C}} '''ua'''- because it normally doesn't get object endings.
In this case the verb form is unchanged but preceded by the particle {{Tengwar|j~C}} '''lá''': * {{Tengwar|9G65$5Ì$8}} '''hirnenyes''' "I have found it" * {{Tengwar|j~C 9G65$5Ì$8}} '''lá hirnenyes''' "I haven't found it" The verb {{Tengwar|`V`C}} '''ëa''' is also always negated by using {{Tengwar|j~C}} '''lá''': * {{Tengwar|`V`C 9U`C5 `B aY`C,F}} '''ëa huan i coassë''' "There is a dog in the house" * {{Tengwar|j~C `V`C 9U`C5 `B aY`C,F}} '''lá ëa huan i coassë''' "there is no dog in the house" ---- >> [[Neo-Quenya]] >> [[../Verbs/]] {{BookCat}}

==to be== Quenya has two verbs that correspond to the English verb "to be": {{Tengwar|5~C}} '''ná''' and {{Tengwar|`V`C}} '''ëa'''. {{Tengwar|5~C}} '''Ná''' is used in the following cases: :to connect two nouns: :* {{Tengwar|iDw$ iG5# 5~C alDt#iD5}} '''sambë sina ná caimasan''' "this room is a bedroom" :to connect a noun and an adjective: :* {{Tengwar|iDw% iG5$ 5#6 qT1ÎR}} '''sambi sinë nar pityë''' "these rooms are small" {{Tengwar|`V`C}} '''Eä''' is used to denote existence at a location: * {{Tengwar|`B 9D6T# `V`C `B iDw$,R}} '''i harma ëa i sambessë''' "the treasure is in the room" * {{Tengwar|`V`C5 1.D7R,R}} '''ëan tauressë''' "I am in a wood" The non-pronominal forms of '''ëa''' can be used without subject to denote "there is" ({{Tengwar|`V`C}} '''ëa''') or "there are" ({{Tengwar|`V`C6}} '''ëar'''): * {{Tengwar|`V`C `Vm# `C8 zGs#}} '''ëa elda as quinga''' "there is an elf with a bow" * {{Tengwar|`V`C6 5#6t^6 `B `N81Y,R}} '''ëar narmor i ostossë''' "there are wolves in the city" '''''Conjugation''''': These verbs have no Perfect tense and the Present and Aorist tenses are identical. * The verb {{Tengwar|5~C}} '''ná''' The Present/Aorist tense of {{Tengwar|5~C}} '''ná''' is formed with the stem {{Tengwar|5#\}} '''na'''-, so we find e.g.: * {{Tengwar|5#5}} '''nan''' "I am", {{Tengwar|5#j´$}} '''nalyë''' "you are", {{Tengwar|5#4$}} '''nantë''' "they are", ... The Past tense is formed with the stem {{Tengwar|5$\}} '''ne'''-, the endless form is {{Tengwar|5~V}} '''né''', e.g.: * {{Tengwar|5$8}} '''nes''' "he/she/it was", {{Tengwar|5$jt$}} '''nelmë''' "we were (excl.)", ... The Future tense is regular with stem {{Tengwar|5.DyE\}} '''nauva'''-: * {{Tengwar|`B 5%,G 5.DyE6 5lD7R}} '''i nissi nauvar nairë''' "the women will be sad" * {{Tengwar|5.DyE5 `C7E5}} '''nauvan aran''' "I shall be king" :The verb {{Tengwar|`V`C}} '''ëa''' The Present/Aorist tense of {{Tengwar|`V`C}} '''ëa''' is regular with the stem {{Tengwar|`V`C\}} '''ëa'''-, so we find e.g.: * {{Tengwar|`V`C5}} '''ëan''' "I am", {{Tengwar|`V`Cj´$}} '''ëalyë''' "you are", {{Tengwar|`V`C4$}} '''ëantë''' "they are", ... The Past tense is formed with the stem {{Tengwar|`Vs$\}} '''enge'''-, e.g.: * {{Tengwar|`Vs$8}} '''enges''' "he/she/it was", {{Tengwar|`Vs$jt$}} '''engelmë''' "we were (excl.)", ... The Future tense is regular with stem {{Tengwar|.FyE\}} '''euva'''-: * {{Tengwar|`B 7Ya;Y6 .FyE6 t#jaY7R,R}} '''i roccor euvar i malcoressë''' "the horses will be in the castle" * {{Tengwar|.FyEjt$ iG5^t$}} '''euvalmë sinomë''' "we shall be here" This verb has a Present Participle {{Tengwar|`V`Cj#}} '''ëala''': * {{Tengwar|`B `N81Y6 `V`Cj#}} '''i ostor ëala''' "the existing cities" ==Impersonal verbs== These verbs have the special property of lacking an explicit subject. In most languages only verbs that denote a condition or weather are of this type: "it rains", "it freezes", ... Such verbs are also impersonal in Quenya: * {{Tengwar|j%q1E}} '''lipta''' "it drips" * {{Tengwar|`MzR}} '''uquë''' "it rains" * {{Tengwar|e.D1E}} '''fauta''' "it snows" * {{Tengwar|9GjaD}} '''hilca''' "it freezes" Note: these verbs don't get the ending {{Tengwar|\8}} -'''s''' even though we translate it into English with the personal pronoun "it". A second group are the impersonal verbs that are also impersonal in English and have an indirect object that indicates to whom the action matters. In Quenya this indirect object is put in the [[../Dative|dative case]]: * {{Tengwar|t#61E}} '''marta'''- "happen" → {{Tengwar|t#61E iR5}} '''marta sen''' "it happens to her" * {{Tengwar|t.DyE}} '''mauya'''- "compel" → {{Tengwar|t.DhÎD 5%5}} '''mauya nin''' "it compels me" * {{Tengwar|5#hÎD}} '''naya'''- "grieve" → {{Tengwar|5#hÎD iY5}} '''naya son''' "it grieves him" * {{Tengwar|`Ns#}} '''onga'''- "pain" → {{Tengwar|`Ns# t$5}} '''onga men''' "it pains us" * {{Tengwar|yTm#}} '''vilda'''- "matter" → {{Tengwar|yTm# j$5}} '''vilda len''' "it matters to you" A longer example: * {{Tengwar|t.DhÎD 5%5 j$j´# `N81Y5:#}} '''mauya nin lelya ostonna''' "I am compelled to go to town" Neo-Quenya also has a few verbs that get an explicit subject in most other languages: * {{Tengwar|`B1T3ÍD\}} '''itisya'''- "itch, irritate" * {{Tengwar|j^hÎD\}} '''loya'''- "be thirsty" * {{Tengwar|~Nj#\}} '''óla'''- "dream" * {{Tengwar|iDd1E\}} '''sahta'''- "be hot" * {{Tengwar|iG1;E}} '''sitta'''- "be used to" * {{Tengwar|`N6\ = `N7E\}} '''or'''-/'''ora'''- "urge, impel" The original English subject changes into a dative in Quenya: * {{Tengwar|`N7R 5%5 aD7T1E8}} '''orë nin caritas''' "it impels me to do it" = "I was impelled to do it" It is also possible to use a dative-subject that is not a personal pronoun: * {{Tengwar|`N7E5$ `B `Vm#5 j$j´#}} '''oranë i eldan lelya''' "the elf was impelled to go" With the verb {{Tengwar|~Mj#\}} '''óla'''- "dream" we find analoguously: * {{Tengwar|~Mj# `B yR2$5 `Vm#7Y5}} '''óla i venden eldaron''' "the girl dreamed about elves (genitive)" In Quenya we consider the dreamer (the girl) not as the agent (subject) of the dream but as the receiver (indirect object). So literally we could say "it dreams to the girl about elves". Sometimes the verb {{Tengwar|5~C}} '''ná''' can also be used impersonally when the predicate is an adjective: * {{Tengwar|5~C 7Ts# 5%5}} '''ná ringa nin''' "it is cold to me" = "I am cold" * {{Tengwar|5~C t~C7E iY5}} '''ná mára son''' "it is good to him" = "he is good" Note: this construction is also possible in German: "Mir ist kalt". ==Causative verbs== These verbs originate with an adjective and their meaning is that one acquires the property expressed by the adjective. They can be formed by adding {{Tengwar|\1E}} -'''ta''' to the adjective: * {{Tengwar|`Cj´#}} '''alya''' "rich" → {{Tengwar|`Cj´#1E}} '''alyata'''- "become rich" Adjectives on {{Tengwar|\`V}} -'''ë''' change this final letter into {{Tengwar|\`B}} -'''i''': * {{Tengwar|lD7R}} '''airë''' "holy" → {{Tengwar|lD7T1E}} '''airita'''- "become holy, hallow" * {{Tengwar|5%v$}} '''ninquë''' "white" → {{Tengwar|5%v%1E}} '''ninquita'''- "become white, whiten" The stress rules imply that these verbs show some irregularities: when an ending is added to the verb that contains exactly one syllable, we change {{Tengwar|\1E}} -'''ta''' into {{Tengwar|\1~C}} -'''tá'''-: * {{Tengwar|`B `C7E5 lD7T1~C5$}} '''i aran airitánë''' "the king hallowed" but * {{Tengwar|`Cj´#1E5$jt$}} '''alyatanelmë''' "we became rich" this phenomenon also appears in the [[../Verbal forms|present participle]]: * {{Tengwar|lD7T1~Cj$}} '''airitálë''' "hallowing" in the [[../Verbal forms|passive participle]] {{Tengwar|\1lD5#}} -'''taina''' changes into {{Tengwar|\4#}} -'''nta''': * {{Tengwar|5%v%4#}} '''ninquinta''' "whitened" ==the verb equë== The verb {{Tengwar|zR1\}} '''quet'''- can mean "say" or "speak" depending on the case with which it is used ([[../Dative|dative]] or [[../Allative|allative]]). With direct or indirect speech (see [[../Syntaxis]]) the verb {{Tengwar|`VzR}} '''equë''' is preferred. The conjugation of this verb is extremely simple: it has only one form that is used for all tenses and all numbers. It is only used when the subject is a proper noun or a personal pronoun (so it cannot be used with an ordinary noun like "father", "king", etc.) * {{Tengwar|`VzR5- a~V}} '''equen: 'cé' '''   "I say/said: 'maybe' " Even the word order is uncommon as it is always placed right before its subject: * {{Tengwar|`VzR `Vj$2%j- `M1~Mj%`V5}} '''equë Elendil: 'utúlien' '''   "Elendil says/said: 'I have come' " * {{Tengwar|`VzR `Cj1E7T`Vj `C6 1Rj$qY65^- 5#t~C7T`V}} '''equë Altariel ar Teleporno: 'namárië' '''   "Galadriel and Celeborn say/said: 'farewell' " It is however never really wrong to use {{Tengwar|zR1\}} '''quet'''-: * {{Tengwar|zR1T5- a~V}} '''quetin: 'cé' '''   "I say: 'maybe' " * {{Tengwar|`Vj$2%j zr4$- `M1~Mj%`V5}} '''Elendil quentë: 'utúlien' '''   "Elendil said: 'I have come' " * {{Tengwar|`Cj1E7T`Vj `C6 1Rj$qY65^ zR4$6- 5#t~C7T`V}} '''Altariel ar Teleporno quenter: 'namárië' '''   "Galadriel and Celeborn said: 'farewell' " And when we use a different subject {{Tengwar|zr1\}} '''quet'''- is obligatory: * {{Tengwar|`B 5~B8 z~V1E- lDhÎD}} '''i nís quéta: 'aiya' '''   "the woman is saying: 'hello' " Also when the subject follows the direct speech we use {{Tengwar|zR1\}} '''quet'''-: * {{Tengwar|`M1~Mj%`V5= zR4$ `Vj$2%j}} ''' 'utúlien', quentë Elendil'''   "'I have come', said Elendil" ==the verb auta-== This verb has three conjugations which depend on the meaning of the verb. The three conjugations coincide in following tenses and verbal forms: Present, Aorist, Future, Present Participle, Gerund, Imperative. 1. pass away This meaning is only used in official texts and only in the Past tense: * {{Tengwar|`B `C7E5 `C5nR}} '''i aran anwë''' "the king passed away" 2. go away, depart This meaning is always associated with a direction. So this conjugation is generally accompanied by an [[../Allative|allative]] noun: * {{Tengwar|`B 5~V6 `H`C4$ `V`C5:#}} '''i nér oantë i ëanna''' "the man departed for the sea"/"the man went away to the sea" The directional complement can of course be implied: * {{Tengwar|`B 5.DaY `H`C4%`V}} '''i nauco oantië''' "the dwarf has departed"/"the dwarf went away" The complete conjugation is: * Past tense: {{Tengwar|`H`C4$}} '''oantë''' * Perfect tense: {{Tengwar|`H`C4%`V}} '''oantië''' * Infinitive: {{Tengwar|.D1E}} '''auta''' * Past participle: {{Tengwar|.D1lD5#}} '''autaina'''. 3. leave, disappear In this meaning no direction is present, so we cannot have an [[../Allative|allative]] complement: * {{Tengwar|hÍ~V5% `Cy~C5%`V6}} '''yéni avánier''' "centuries have disappeared, have gone by" * {{Tengwar|`B iRm^ y~C5$}} '''i seldo vánë''' "the boy disappeared"/"the boy left" (note: the meaning "leave behind" is not expressed by {{Tengwar|.D1E\}} '''auta'''- but by {{Tengwar|j$81E}} '''lesta'''-). The past participle is also used with the meaning "lost" (i.e. "cannot be regained"): * {{Tengwar|yEj%t#6 5~C yE5nE}} '''Valimar ná vanwa''' "Valimar is lost" The complete conjugation is: * Past tense: {{Tengwar|yE5$}} '''vánë''' * Perfect tense: {{Tengwar|`Cy~C5%`V}} '''avánië''' * Infinitive: {{Tengwar|yE5nR}} '''vanwë''' * Past participle: {{Tengwar|yE5nE}} '''vanwa'''. ---- >> [[Neo-Quenya]] >> [[../Verbs/]] >> [[../Special Verbs/]] {{BookCat}}

==Infinitive== The infinitive is used after verbs that influence the meaning of other verbs: :The verbs <small>{{Tengwar|qYj\}}</small> '''pol'''- "can" and <small>{{Tengwar|t$6\}}</small> '''mer'''- "wish, want":
:* <small>{{Tengwar|qYj%5 zR1R}}</small> '''polin quetë''' "I can talk"
:* <small>{{Tengwar|t# qYj%j aR5$ 5%5À}}</small> '''ma polil cenë nin?''' "Can you see me?"
:* <small>{{Tengwar|`B 5.DaY6 t$65$6 t#1R}}</small> '''i naucor merner matë''' "the dwarves wanted to eat"
:* <small>{{Tengwar|`B iRm^ qYj°$ ½j#7R `Bj´# zR1;E}}</small> '''i seldo pollë hlarë ilya quetta''' "the boy could hear each word"
:* <small>{{Tengwar|t$7T5 aR2# `B qE6t#}}</small> '''merin cenda i parma''' "I want to read the book"
:Verbs that indicate that an action starts, ends or changes: :* <small>{{Tengwar|`B 5%,G qU81E5$6 j%2#}}</small> '''i nissi pustaner linda''' "the women stopped to sing"
:* <small>{{Tengwar|`B 5$7T hÎR81E5$6 t#1R}}</small> '''i neri yestaner matë''' "the men began to eat"
:The negating verb <small>{{Tengwar|`Mt\}}</small> '''um'''- (see [[../Verbs/]]).
Note: the word "to" that sometimes precedes an English infinitive is never translated into Neo-Quenya.
'''''Formation''''':
This is easy because the infinitive is always equal to the endingless form of the aorist: * for A-verbs this is equals the dictionary stem: <small>{{Tengwar|j%2#\}}</small> '''linda'''- "sing" → <small>{{Tengwar|j%2#}}</small> '''linda''' * for primitive verbs we fins the ending <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''': <small>{{Tengwar|zR1\}}</small> '''quet'''- "speak, talk" → <small>{{Tengwar|zR1R}}</small> '''quetë''' * for U-verbs the final -'''u''' of the stem becomes <small>{{Tengwar|\`N}}</small> -'''o''': <small>{{Tengwar|qEj&\}}</small> '''palu'''- "spread" → <small>{{Tengwar|qEj^}}</small> '''palo'''
===Long Infinitive===
One of the most distinguishing properties of Quenya is the presence of object endings. So when an infinitive takes a personal pronoun as object then the infinitive is lengthened and the object ending is added. * <small>{{Tengwar|`B t~Nj yR7ÎD5$ aR5$ `B `C7E5 `C6 `B 1~C7T}}</small> '''i mól veryanë cenë i aran ar i tári''' "the slave dared to look at the king and queen" When we replace "the king and queen" by a personal pronoun this is changed into: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B t~Nj yR7ÎD5$ aR5%1E1}}</small> '''i mól veryanë cenitat''' "the slave dared to look at them"
The long infinitive is formed by adding <small>{{Tengwar|\1E}}</small> -'''ta''' to the stem of A-verbs and U-verbs, and <small>{{Tengwar|\`B1E}}</small> -'''ita''' to the stem of primitive verbs: * <small>{{Tengwar|aD6\}}</small> '''car'''- "make, do, build" → <small>{{Tengwar|aD7T1E\}}</small> '''carita'''-
* <small>{{Tengwar|t#qE\}}</small> '''mapa'''- "take, catch" → <small>{{Tengwar|t#qE1E\}}</small> '''mapata'''-
* <small>{{Tengwar|qEj&\}}</small> '''palu'''- "spread" → <small>{{Tengwar|qEj&1E\}}</small> '''paluta'''-
The long infinitive never appears without object ending, e.g. * <small>{{Tengwar|qUj%5 `N61E1E8}}</small> '''polin ortatas''' "I can lift it"
* <small>{{Tengwar|`B `Nd1E7T ~MyE6 t#qE1E1}}</small> '''i ohtari úvar mapatat''' "the soldiers will not catch them"
The long infinitive can also be used with possessive endings, but this can be found on the page [[../Possessive pronouns/]].
===Passive Infinitive=== There is a complication when we want to use an infinitive in a [[../Syntaxis|passive sentence]].
Look at the following sentence: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B 5.DaY6 qYj%6 t#1R `B `CqE¡}}</small> '''i naucor polir matë i apsa''' "the dwarves can eat the food" The verb <small>{{Tengwar|t#1\}}</small> '''mat'''- "to eat" is in the infinitive because it appears behind the modal verb <small>{{Tengwar|qYj\}}</small> '''pol'''- "can".
When we make these sentences passive, the infinitive gets the prefix <small>{{Tengwar|`C\}}</small> '''a'''-: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B `CqE¡ qYj$ `Ct#1R 1B 5.DalY5$5}}</small> '''i apsa polë amatë i naucoinen''' "the food can be eaten by the dwarves"
Verbs that begin in a vowel instead have the long infinitive suffix: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B aY6t# qYj$ 5#4#1E `C1E7T5Ì#5}}</small> '''i corma polë antata atarinyan''' "the ring can be given to my father"
In some verbs very likely the historical stems appear when we apply the prefix: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B t#,D qYj$ `Cw#81E}}</small> '''i massa polë ambasta''' "the bread can be baked" The verb <small>{{Tengwar|t#81E}}</small> '''masta'''- "to bake" has a historical stem '''mbasta'''- that reappears when a prefix is put in front of it: <small>{{Tengwar|`Cw#81E}}</small> '''ambasta'''.
For more on this see the page on the [[../Perfect Tense|perfect tense]].
==Participles== A Neo-Quenya verb has 2 participles: the active and the passive participle.
===Active participle===
The Active participle can be used in two ways: :as <u>an adjective</u>: in this case it is always put behind the noun: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B iRm^ t~C1Ej#}}</small> '''i seldo mátala''' "the eating boy"
:as <u>a main verb</u> in a sub-sentence that in English begins with "while": * <small>{{Tengwar|t~C1Ej# t#7T5<nowiki>=</nowiki> `B 5~V6 aR2#5$ qE6t#}}</small> '''mátala marin, i nér cendanë parma''' "while (he was) eating an apple, the man read a book" and sometimes we also drop "while": * <small>{{Tengwar|t~C1Ej# t#7T5<nowiki>=</nowiki> `B 5~V6 aR2#5$ qE6t#}}</small> '''mátala marin, i nér cendanë parma''' "eating an apple, the man read a book"
The active participle doesn't have a plural: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B iRm^6 t~C1EjE}}</small> '''i seldor mátala''' "the eating boys" But it can be declined in all 9 cases because it follows the rule of <u>the last declinable word</u> (see the page [[../Inflected adjectives/]]): * <small>{{Tengwar|`BiGjt$ `BjaDj#,R}}</small> '''isilmë ilcalassë''' "in gleaming moonlight" (locative ending) When the noun is in the plural, dual or the partitive plural the case ending of the participle is plural: * <small>{{Tengwar|yR2% j%2#jlDyE}}</small> '''vendi lindalaiva''' "of singing girls" (possessive plural ending)
When an Active participle has a direct object, this object always immediately follows the participle: * <small>{{Tengwar|5.DaY 1~B7Ej# `Vm#}}</small> '''nauco tírala elda''' "an elf-watching dwarf"/"a dwarf that is/was watching an elf"
Note: the Active participle is never used predicatively or as a noun. Instead of both these uses Quenya uses the present tense instead.
When used as a noun, it becomes a present tense preceded by the article (this corresponds to the use of the article as a [[../Pronouns|relative pronoun]] without antecedent): * <small>{{Tengwar|`B aR2$`C}}</small> '''i cendëa''' "he/she who is reading"
* <small>{{Tengwar|`B t~C1E6}}</small> '''i mátar''' "they who are eating"
'''''Formation''''':
The A-stems and U-stems form their active participle by lengthening the central vowel and adding the suffix -'''la''': * <small>{{Tengwar|t#qE\}}</small> '''mapa'''- "take" → <small>{{Tengwar|t~CqEj#}}</small> '''mápala''' "taking"
* <small>{{Tengwar|j#j#\}}</small> '''lala'''- "laugh" → <small>{{Tengwar|j~Cj#j#}}</small> '''lálala''' "laughing"
* <small>{{Tengwar|½j#qU\}}</small> '''hlapu'''- "blow" → <small>{{Tengwar|½j~CqUj#}}</small> '''hlápula''' "blowing" When the syllable of the central vowel is already long, this vowel cannot be lengthened: * <small>{{Tengwar|9.D1E\}}</small> '''hauta'''- "stop" → <small>{{Tengwar|9.D1Ej#}}</small> '''hautala''' "stopping"
* <small>{{Tengwar|q~BaD\}}</small> '''píca'''- "diminish" → <small>{{Tengwar|q~BaDj#}}</small> '''pícala''' "diminishing"
* <small>{{Tengwar|5&7;U\}}</small> '''nurru'''- "grumble" → <small>{{Tengwar|5&7;Uj#}}</small> '''nurrula''' "grumbling"
The primitive verbs also have a lengthened central vowel and they get the ending -'''ala''': * <small>{{Tengwar|1T6\}}</small> '''tir'''- "watch" → <small>{{Tengwar|1~B7Ej#}}</small> '''tírala''' "watching"
* <small>{{Tengwar|9Ca\}}</small> '''hac'''- "yawn" → <small>{{Tengwar|9~CaDj#}}</small> '''hácala''' "yawning"
* <small>{{Tengwar|t#1\}}</small> '''mat'''- "eat" → <small>{{Tengwar|t~C1Ej#}}</small> '''mátala''' "eating"
===Passive participle=== The passive participle is in Quenya only used as an adjective as it isn't needed to form the [[../Perfect Tense|perfect tenses]]. It is called this way because with a transitive verb it can be used predicatively to form the passive voice (see [[../Syntaxis/]]): * <small>{{Tengwar|`B `C1E5% 9C65lDD5$}}</small> '''i atani harnainë''' "the wounded men" → <small>{{Tengwar|`B `C1E5% 5#6 9C65lD5$}}</small> '''i atani nar harnainë''' "the men are (i.e., have been) wounded"
* <small>{{Tengwar|`B `N2^ `N61lD5#}}</small> '''i ondo ortaina''' "the lifted stone" → <small>{{Tengwar|`B `N2^ 5~C `N61lD5#}}</small> '''i ondo ná ortaina''' "the stone is lifted"
For an intransitive verb it can only be used with a noun and in that case it is used to denote completion of the action: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B 5~V6 j#4lD5#}}</small> '''i nér lantaina''' "the fallen man"
From these examples it should already be clear that the passive participle has a plural form on <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''', in fact it behaves like an ordinary adjective on <small>{{Tengwar|\`C}}</small> -'''a''' (so it also can get case endings when following its noun; see [[../Inflected adjectives/]]).
'''''Formation''''':
The A-stems and U-stems form their passive participle by adding the suffix -'''ina'''. This suffix merges with the final -'''a''' or -'''u''' into the diphtongs -'''ai''' and -'''ui'''. According to the stress rules (see [[../Phonology/]]), these diphtongs are always stressed. * <small>{{Tengwar|`C4#\}}</small> '''anta'''- "give" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C4lD5#}}</small> '''antaina''' "given"
* <small>{{Tengwar|qR7ÎD\}}</small> '''perya'''- "halve" → <small>{{Tengwar|qR7ÎlD5#}}</small> '''peryaina''' "halved"
* <small>{{Tengwar|t#qE\}}</small> '''mapa'''- "take, catch" → <small>{{Tengwar|t#qlD5#}}</small> '''mapaina''' "taken, caught"
* <small>{{Tengwar|t^7Y\}}</small> '''moru'''- "conceal" → <small>{{Tengwar|t^7lU5#}}</small> '''moruina''' "concealed" (vs. also supposable <small>{{Tengwar|t^7~M5#}}</small> '''morúna''' - cf. ''The Silmarillion'', ch. XXI)
The primitive verbs can be divided into three categories: :verbs ending on -'''c''', -'''p''', -'''t''', -'''v''', -'''s''' also get the ending <small>{{Tengwar|\`B5#}}</small> -'''ina''' but in these verbs the central vowel is lengthened: * <small>{{Tengwar|7Ea\}}</small> '''rac'''- "break" → <small>{{Tengwar|7~CaG5#}}</small> '''rácina''' "broken"
* <small>{{Tengwar|1Yq\}}</small> '''top'''- "cover" → <small>{{Tengwar|1~NqT5#}}</small> '''tópina''' "covered"
* <small>{{Tengwar|5^1\}}</small> '''not'''- "count" → <small>{{Tengwar|5~N1T5#}}</small> '''nótina''' "counted"
* <small>{{Tengwar|j#y\}}</small> '''lav'''- "allow" → <small>{{Tengwar|j~CyT5#}}</small> '''lávina''' "allowed"
* <small>{{Tengwar|iG8\}}</small> '''sis'''- "fry" → <small>{{Tengwar|8~BiG5#}}</small> '''sísina''' "fried"
:verbs in -'''qu''' also follow this rule, but the central vowel cannot be lengthened (and '''qui''' doesn't contain a diphtong as it pronounced '''cwi'''): * <small>{{Tengwar|t%z\}}</small> '''miqu'''- "kiss" → <small>{{Tengwar|t%zG5#}}</small> '''miquina''' "kissed"
:verbs ending on -'''r''', -'''m''', -'''n''' receive the ending -'''na''': * <small>{{Tengwar|t$6\}}</small> '''mer'''- "want" → <small>{{Tengwar|t$65#}}</small> '''merna''' "wanted"
* <small>{{Tengwar|5#t\}}</small> '''nam'''- "judge" → <small>{{Tengwar|5#t5#}}</small> '''namna''' "judged"
* <small>{{Tengwar|aR5\}}</small> '''cen'''- "see" → <small>{{Tengwar|aR5:#}}</small> '''cenna''' "seen"
:verbs on -'''l''' get -'''da''' as ending: * <small>{{Tengwar|t$j\}}</small> '''mel'''- "love" → <small>{{Tengwar|t$m#}}</small> '''melda''' "loved"
Note: Verbs can also form a verbal adjective. These adjectives always denote a static condition while past participle always denote a condition in evolution: * <small>{{Tengwar|9C65#\}}</small> '''harna'''- "wound"
* <small>{{Tengwar|9C65#}}</small> '''harna''' "with a wound"
* <small>{{Tengwar|9C65lD5#}}</small> '''harnaina''' "wounded"
* <small>{{Tengwar|zD1\}}</small> '''quat'''- "fill"
* <small>{{Tengwar|zD4#}}</small> '''quanta''' "full"
* <small>{{Tengwar|z~C1T5#}}</small> '''quátina''' "filled"
==Gerund== The gerund is a combination of a verb and a noun. In English it has the same form as the present participle, e.g. "walking is healthy". The noun "walking" is called the gerund of the verb "walk".
As an example let's look at some Quenya sentences: * <small>{{Tengwar|9C7T`V t#j1E ~MyE aD7R 5~V6 `C5nEyR `Cj´#}}</small> '''harië malta úva carë nér anwavë alya''' "having gold doesn't make a man really rich"
* <small>{{Tengwar|t#1T`V 5~C `C5#j1E `Cj$,R `Bj´$ 5.DaY7Y5}}</small> '''matië ná i analta alessë ilyë Naucoron''' "eating is the greatest joy of all dwarves"
A gerund can also have a direct object: * <small>{{Tengwar|9G7T`V 9C6t# aD7UyE 5~V6 `Cj´#}}</small> '''hirië harma caruva nér alya''' "finding a treasure shall make a man rich"
* <small>{{Tengwar|1T7T`V lDnT `C4# `B yR2%5 `Cj1E `Cj#,R}}</small> '''tirië aiwi anta i vendin alta alassë''' "watching birds gives a girl great pleasure" (note: the object of the gerund is in the [[Quenya/Nominative|nominative]] and not in the [[Quenya/Genitive|genitive]] as with a [[Quenya/Verbal nouns|verbal noun]])
and an indirect object: * <small>{{Tengwar|`C4%`V t#j1E `B `C7E5$5 5~C jlD t#5$}}</small> '''antië malta i aranen ná lai manë''' "giving gold to the king is very good"
In all these examples the gerund replaces the subject of the original sentence, it can however also replace the direct object: * <small>{{Tengwar|t$j%5 1T7T`V lDnT}}</small> '''melin tirië aiwi''' "I love watching birds"
There is a clear difference between infinitives (see above) and gerunds, as infinitives cannot be replaced by a normal noun: * <small>{{Tengwar|qYj%5 zR1R}}</small> '''polin quetë''' "I can talk" In this sentence you cannot replace talk by e.g. "nature", because *"I can nature" is not a good English sentence. But "I love nature" is a good sentence, so '''tirië''' has to be a gerund, and '''quetë''' an infinitive.
'''''Formation''''':
The ending of the gerund is <small>{{Tengwar|\`B`V}}</small> -'''ië'''.
Gerunds of primitive verbs are made by simply adding this ending: * <small>{{Tengwar|zR1\}}</small> '''quet'''- "say, speak" → <small>{{Tengwar|zR1T`V}}</small> '''quetië'''
A-verbs and U-verbs drop their final vowel before adding the ending: * <small>{{Tengwar|`N61E\}}</small> '''orta'''- "stand, get up" → <small>{{Tengwar|`N61T`V}}</small> '''ortië'''
* <small>{{Tengwar|5lD5#\}}</small> '''naina'''- "lament" → <small>{{Tengwar|5lD5%`V}}</small> '''nainië''' Note that this form is identical to the [[../Verbal nouns|verbal noun]] '''nainië'''. This is often the case, analysis of the context has to decide whether it is a gerund or a verbal noun.
Verbs on <small>{{Tengwar|\hÎD}}</small> -'''ya''' drop this ending completely before adding <small>{{Tengwar|\`B`V}}</small> -'''ië''': * <small>{{Tengwar|9C7ÎD\}}</small> '''harya'''- "have, possess" → <small>{{Tengwar|9C7T`V}}</small> '''harië'''
* <small>{{Tengwar|yR7ÎD}}</small> '''verya'''- "dare" → <small>{{Tengwar|yR7T`V}}</small> '''verië'''
===Cases of the gerund===
In Quenya the gerund can be declined into three cases: :[[../Genitive|Genitive]]: This case appears when a gerund is dependent on a [[../Verbal nouns|verbal noun]]: * <small>{{Tengwar|aD6t$ 1RaT~V`N}}</small> '''carmë teciéo''' "art of writing"
:[[../Dative/]]: We use the dative to express "in order to": * <small>{{Tengwar|t~N1E8 alU5%`V5}}</small> '''mótas cuinien''' "he works in order to live" But in English the words "in order" are mostly implicitly understood, so to use this case properly you will have to be careful when meeting an English "to" + infinitive: ::<small>{{Tengwar|`M1~Mj%`V4$ aR5%`V5 `B `C7E5}}</small> '''utúlientë cenien i aran''' "they had come to see the king"
:[[../Instrumental/]]: We use the instrumental to express "through, by": * <small>{{Tengwar|5^j°$8 t#d1T`V 1T7T`V5$5 `B `Nd1E7T}}</small> '''nolles mahtië tirienen i ohtari''' "he learned to fight through/by watching the soldiers"
==Negation== All verbal forms are negated by use of the particle <small>{{Tengwar|j~C}}</small> '''lá''' (see also Negation on the page [[../Verbs/]]).
Infinitives: :Here we find a difference in meaning between negation with <small>{{Tengwar|}}</small> '''lá''' and with <small>{{Tengwar|`Mt\}}</small> '''um'''-: * <small>{{Tengwar|8lDj# 5~C j~C aD7T1E8}}</small> '''saila ná lá caritas''' "it is wise not to do it"
* <small>{{Tengwar|8lDj# `Mt$ aD7T1E8}}</small> '''saila umë caritas''' "it is not wise to do it"
Participles: * <small>{{Tengwar|`B iYm^6 9~CaDj#}}</small> '''i soldor hácala''' "the yawning boys"
* <small>{{Tengwar|`B iYm^6 j~C 9~CaDj#}}</small> '''i soldor lá hácala''' "the not yawning boys"
* <small>{{Tengwar|`B 9C6t# 9Cj´lD5#}}</small> '''i harma halyaina''' "the hidden treasure"
* <small>{{Tengwar|`B 9C6t# j~C 9Cj´lD5#}}</small> '''i harma lá halyaina''' "the not hidden treasure"
Gerund: * <small>{{Tengwar|zR1T`V 5~C 1RjqR}}</small> '''quetië ná telpë''' "speaking is silver"
* <small>{{Tengwar|j~C zR1T`V 5~C t#j1#}}</small> '''lá quetië ná malta''' "not speaking is gold"
----
>> [[Neo-Quenya]] >> [[../Verbs/]] >> [[../Verbal forms/]]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Forgot one important character in a few sentences, the Á!
revision.text:
The Imperative is used to issue commands. ==Ancient Imperative== The ancient form of the imperative is only used with primitive verbs. It is formed by adding {{Tengwar|\`C}} -'''a''' to the stem without lengthening the stem-vowel (so it is like the present tense but with a short central vowel): ::{{Tengwar|1T7EÁ}} '''tira!''' "watch!" This imperative is very direct, so you shouldn't use it when you want to be polite. ==Standard Imperative== This is formed by placing the particle {{Tengwar|~C}} '''á''' before the [[../Verbal forms|infinitive]]: ::{{Tengwar|~C 1T7RÁ}} '''á tirë!''' "watch!" ::{{Tengwar|~C yEj#Á}} '''á vala!''' "rule!" When the central vowel of the infinitive is long, a diphtong or followed by more than one consonant we use the particle {{Tengwar|`C}} '''a''' instead of {{Tengwar|~C}} '''á''' (but this is not obligatory, so using {{Tengwar|~C}} '''á''' is never wrong): ::{{Tengwar|`C alDt#Á}} '''a caima!''' "lie down!" ::{{Tengwar|`C t~N1EÁ}} '''a móta!''' "work!" ::{{Tengwar|`C j%2#Á}} '''a linda!''' "sing!" The combinations {{Tengwar|7Î}} '''ry''', {{Tengwar|j´}} '''ly''', {{Tengwar|5Ì}} '''ny''', {{Tengwar|1Î}} '''ty''' do not count as a double consonant, so when the central vowel is immediately followed by any one of these we use {{Tengwar|~C}} '''á''': ::{{Tengwar|~C j$j´#´Á}} '''á lelya!''' "go!" but ::{{Tengwar|`C t%4Ì#Á}} '''a mintya!''' "remember!" The particle is pronounced as a unit with these infinitives, so the stress is normally on the particle {{Tengwar|~C}} '''á''' and not on {{Tengwar|`C}} '''a''' (the exceptions are verbs with an infinitive of more than two syllables). ===negative imperative=== A prohibition or negative imperative is formed by the particle {{Tengwar|~CyE}} '''áva'''. It is the same for all verbs: ::{{Tengwar|~CyE j$j´#Á}} '''áva lelya!''' "don't go!" ::{{Tengwar|~CyE 1T7RÁ}} '''áva tirë!''' "don't look!" It can also be used on its own, but then the long vowel is shifted: ::{{Tengwar|`Cy~CÁ}} '''avá!''' "don't!" (note: this is the only two-syllable word that is stressed on the final syllable; see [[../Phonology/]]) ==Personal pronouns with the imperative== When a verb is in the imperative it can have personal pronouns that refer to the subject, the direct object or the indirect object. ===subject pronouns=== A reference to the subject is not very frequent, only when it is absolutely necessary to specify to whom the command is directed: "Listen you!" The Quenya endings are {{Tengwar|\1}} -'''t''' in the singular and {{Tengwar|\j}} -'''l''' in the plural: ::{{Tengwar|`C j%2#1Á}} '''a lindat!''' "sing you!" (singular) ::{{Tengwar|`C j%2#jÁ}} '''a lindal!''' "sing you!" (plural) With a primitive verb the connecting vowel is {{Tengwar|\`B\}} -'''i'''- as usual: ::{{Tengwar|~C1T7RÁ}} '''á tirë!''' "watch!" ::{{Tengwar|~C 1T7T1Á \ ~C 1T7TjÁ}} '''á tirit!'''/'''á tiril!''' "watch you!" These endings can also be used in the negative imperative: ::{{Tengwar|~CyE 1Uj$Á}} '''áva tulë!''' "don't come!" ::{{Tengwar|~CyE 1Uj%11Á \ ~CyE 1Uj%jÁ}} '''áva tulit!'''/'''áva tulil!''' "don't come you!" ===direct object pronouns=== To indicate the direct object we can use the nominative of the independant [[../Personal pronouns|personal pronouns]]: ::{{Tengwar|`C jlD1E 1RÁ}} '''a laita te!''' "bless them!" ::{{Tengwar|~C 1T7R 5Ì$Á}} '''á tirë nye!''' "watch me!" It is however also possible to add this nominative as an ending to the particle {{Tengwar|~C}} '''á'''.
This could be used for less emphasis on the direct object so it is not as commanding (in this situation we always use {{Tengwar|~C}} '''á''' never {{Tengwar|`C}} '''a'''): ::{{Tengwar|~C1R jlD1EÁ}} '''átë laita!''' "bless them!" ::{{Tengwar|~C5Ì$ 1T7RÁ}} '''ányë tirë!''' "watch me!" Also with the negative imperative both forms are possible: ::{{Tengwar|~CyEt$ 1T7RÁ}} '''ávamë tirë!''' "don't watch us!" ::{{Tengwar|~CyE 1T7R t$Á}} '''áva tirë me!''' "don't watch us!" ===indirect object pronouns=== With an indirect object we obviously use the [[../Dative|dative]] forms of the pronouns: ::{{Tengwar|~Ct$5 j%2#Á}} '''ámen linda!''' "sing for us!" When a verb has both a direct and an indirect object, you have the choice which is applied to the particle {{Tengwar|~CyE}} '''á''' or {{Tengwar|~CyE}} '''áva''' and which is used a separate word: ::{{Tengwar|~C5%5 aD7R 1EÁ}} '''ánin carë ta!''' "do it for me!" ::{{Tengwar|~C1E aD7R 5%5Á}} '''áta carë nin!''' "do it for me!" ---- >> [[Neo-Quenya]] >> [[../Verbs/]] >> [[../Imperative/]] {{BookCat}}

==Regular formation== The basic ending to form the Past Tense is {{Tengwar|\5$}} -'''në'''. Following verbs follow the regular formation: :A-stem verbs with a long central syllable that do not end on {{Tengwar|\hÍE}} -'''ya''' :* {{Tengwar|9.D1E\}} '''hauta'''- "stop" → {{Tengwar|`B `Vm# 9.D1E5$}} '''i elda hautanë''' "the elf stopped" :* {{Tengwar|j&,D\}} '''lussa'''- "whisper" → {{Tengwar|j&,D5$t:$}} '''lussanemmë''' "we both whispered" :* {{Tengwar|t~N1E\}} '''móta'''- "labour" → {{Tengwar|t~N1E5$j´$}} '''mótanelyë''' "you laboured" :* {{Tengwar|`Cq1E\}} '''apta'''- "deny" → {{Tengwar|`Cq1E5$5Ì$}} '''aptanenyë''' "I denied" :U-stem verbs with a long central syllable: :* {{Tengwar|5&7;U\}} '''nurru'''- "grumble" → {{Tengwar|5&7;U5$5}} '''nurrunen''' "I grumbled" :Primitive verbs on {{Tengwar|\6 \5 \t}} -'''r''', -'''n''' or -'''m''': :* {{Tengwar|1T6\}} '''tir'''- "watch" → {{Tengwar|1T65$8}} '''tirnes''' "he watched" :* {{Tengwar|1Et\}} '''tam'''- "tap" → {{Tengwar|1Et5$1R8}} '''tamnentes''' "they tapped it" :* {{Tengwar|aF5\}} '''cen'''- "see" → {{Tengwar|aF5:$5 `B `Cm#}} '''cennen i alda''' "I saw the tree" ==Primitive verbs== ===nasal inversion=== The primitive verbs that end in {{Tengwar|\1= \a= \q= \j= \z-}} -'''t''', -'''c''', -'''p''', -'''l''', -'''qu''' undergo the so called nasal inversion because the {{Tengwar|\5}} -'''n''' of the past ending is placed before these consonants
(the reason is that the clusters: {{Tengwar|15= a5= q5= j5= z5-}} '''tn''', '''cn''', '''pn''', '''ln''', '''cwn''' are not allowed in Quenya). * {{Tengwar|t#1\}} '''mat'''- "eat" → {{Tengwar|t#4$}} '''mantë''' "ate" * {{Tengwar|9C1\}} '''hat'''- "break" → {{Tengwar|9C4$}} '''hantë''' "broke" * {{Tengwar|1Ea\}} '''tac'''- "fasten" → {{Tengwar|1Ef$}} '''tancë''' "fastened" * {{Tengwar|qRz\}} '''pequ'''- "comb" → {{Tengwar|qRv$}} '''penquë''' "combed" When a primitive verb ends in {{Tengwar|q}} '''p''', [[Quenya/Phonology]] dictates that {{Tengwar|5q}} '''np''' changes to {{Tengwar|r}} '''mp''': :* {{Tengwar|1Yq\}} '''top'''- "cover" → {{Tengwar|1Yr$}} '''tompë''' "covered" And {{Tengwar|5j}} '''nl''' changes into {{Tengwar|j°}} '''ll''': :* {{Tengwar|nTj\}} '''wil'''- "fly" → {{Tengwar|nTj°$}} '''willë''' "flew" There is one final group that undergoes nasal inversion, these are the verbs on -'''d'''. In modern Quenya, a single '''d''' changes into {{Tengwar|7-6}} '''r'''. Careful consideration is needed when we meet a primitive verb on {{Tengwar|\6}} -'''r''', because if this '''r''' descends from a '''d''', its past tense changes into {{Tengwar|2}} '''nd''' (otherwise the past tense is regular, see above). Following verbs belong to this group: * {{Tengwar|9C6\}} '''har'''- "sit" → {{Tengwar|9C2$}} '''handë''' "sat" * {{Tengwar|9ÍC6\}} '''hyar'''- "plough" → {{Tengwar|9ÍC2$}} '''hyandë''' "ploughed" * {{Tengwar|5%6\}} '''nir'''- "press" → {{Tengwar|5%2$}} '''nindë''' "pressed" * {{Tengwar|zT6\}} '''quir'''- "stir" → {{Tengwar|zT2$}} '''quindë''' "stirred" * {{Tengwar|zY6\}} '''quor'''- "choke" → {{Tengwar|zY2$}} '''quondë''' "choked" * {{Tengwar|7D6\}} '''rar'''- "peel" → {{Tengwar|7D2$}} '''randë''' "peeled" * {{Tengwar|7R6\}} '''rer'''- "sow" → {{Tengwar|7R2$}} '''rendë''' "sowed" * {{Tengwar|iR6\}} '''ser'''- "rest" → {{Tengwar|iR2$}} '''sendë''' "rested" * {{Tengwar|iT6\}} '''sir'''- "flow" → {{Tengwar|iT2$}} '''sindë''' "flowed" ===vowel lengthening=== The primitive verbs that end in {{Tengwar|\y}} -'''v''' or {{Tengwar|\8}} -'''s''' do not get the regular ending {{Tengwar|\5$}} -'''në''', but instead lengthens the central vowel and gets the ending {{Tengwar|\`V}} -'''ë''': * {{Tengwar|1Uy\}} '''tuv'''- "find" → {{Tengwar|1~MyR}} '''túvë''' "found" * {{Tengwar|1ÎEy}} '''tyav'''- "taste" → {{Tengwar|1Î~CyR}} '''tyávë''' "tasted" * {{Tengwar|iT8\}} '''sis'''- "fry" → {{Tengwar|8~BiR}} '''sísë''' "fried" ==A-stems/U-stems with short central syllable== These verbs can be conjugated by the regular formation, but most of the time their final {{Tengwar|\`C}} -'''a''' or {{Tengwar|\`M}} -'''u''' is dropped and they are conjugated as if they were primitive verbs: * {{Tengwar|aDyE\}} '''cava'''- "dig" → {{Tengwar|a~CyR}} '''cávë''' "dug" (or {{Tengwar|aDyE5$}} ''cavanë'') * {{Tengwar|t#aD\}} '''maca'''- "forge" → {{Tengwar|t#f$}} '''mancë''' "forged" (or {{Tengwar|t#aD5$}} ''macanë'') * {{Tengwar|5#zD\}} '''naqua'''- "steal" → {{Tengwar|5#v$}} '''nanquë''' "stole" (or {{Tengwar|5#zD5$}} ''naquanë'') * {{Tengwar|½j#qU\}} '''hlapu'''- "blow" → {{Tengwar|½j#r$}} '''hlampë''' "blew" (or {{Tengwar|½j#qU5$}} ''hlapunë'') * {{Tengwar|j&1U\}} '''lutu'''- "float" → {{Tengwar|j&4$}} '''luntë''' "floated" (or {{Tengwar|j&1U5$}} ''lutunë'') These two verbs can never be conjugated by the regular ending: * {{Tengwar|qEqE\}} '''papa'''- "tremble" → {{Tengwar|qEr$}} '''pampë''' "trembled" * {{Tengwar|qE1E\}} '''pata'''- "rap" → {{Tengwar|qE4$}} '''pantë''' "rapped" The verbs on {{Tengwar|\nE}} -'''wa''' only apply in this case: * {{Tengwar|eDnE\}} '''fawa'''- "smell" → {{Tengwar|eDx$}} '''fangwë''' "smelled" (or {{Tengwar|eDnE5$}} ''fawanë'') * {{Tengwar|7DnE\}} '''rawa'''- "run" → {{Tengwar|7Dx$}} '''rangwë''' "ran" (or {{Tengwar|7DnE5$}} ''rawanë'') And verbs on {{Tengwar|\9C}} -'''ha''' are always regular: * {{Tengwar|5Ì$9C\}} '''nyeha'''- "weep" → {{Tengwar|5Ì$9C5$}} '''nyehanë''' "wept" Note: the central syllable in {{Tengwar|5#a|D\}} '''maxa'''- "cook" and {{Tengwar|7Ua|D\}} '''ruxa'''- "crumble" is long as {{Tengwar|a|}} '''x''' is short for the consonant combination '''cs'''. ==A-stem verbs on -'''ya'''== These verbs have two different past tenses which are used depending on whether it is used transitively or intransitively. A verb is used transitively when it has a direct object, and intransitively when it doesn't have a direct object. * when a verb on {{Tengwar|hÍE}} -'''ya''' is used transitively it has a regular past tense, * when a verb on {{Tengwar|hÍE}} -'''ya''' is used intransitively its past tense is formed by dropping the ending {{Tengwar|hÍE}} -'''ya''' and conjugating it as if it were a primitive verb. So we have three cases: :transitive verbs which require a direct object, these are always regular: :* {{Tengwar|9C7ÎE\}} '''harya'''- "have, possess" → {{Tengwar|9C7ÎE5$}} '''haryanë''' "had, possessed" :* {{Tengwar|9C7ÎE5$8 7Ya;Y}} '''haryanes rocco''' "he had a horse" :intransitive verbs (these cannot have a direct object), they are always conjugated as primitive verbs: :* {{Tengwar|j#tÌ#\}} '''lamya-''' "sound" → {{Tengwar|j#t5$}} '''lamnë''' "sounded" :* {{Tengwar|`B 5Ì$j°% j#t5$6}} '''i nyelli lamner''' "the bells sounded" :transitive verbs that can be used intransitively, these verbs have two forms in the past tense: :* {{Tengwar|`Mj´#\}} '''ulya-''' "pour, overflow" → {{Tengwar|`Mj´#5$}} '''ulyanë''' "poured" and {{Tengwar|`Mj°$}} '''ullë''' "overflowed" ::* {{Tengwar|`B 5~B8 `Mj´#5$ 5~V5}} '''i nís ulyanë nén''' "the woman poured water" ::* {{Tengwar|`B 8~B7R `Mj´$}} '''i sírë ullë''' "the river overflowed" :* {{Tengwar|hÍR7ÎE\}} '''yerya-''' "wear out, get old" → {{Tengwar|hÍ7ÎE5$}} '''yeryanë''' "wore out" and {{Tengwar|hÍR65$}} '''yernë''' "got old" ::* {{Tengwar|`B 5~V6 hÍR7ÎE5$ `B aYj´#}} '''i nér yeryanë i colla''' "the man wore the cloak out" ::* {{Tengwar|`B 5~V6 hÍR65$}} '''i nér yernë''' "the man got old" ==Irregular Past Tenses== Some verbs are completely irregular: * {{Tengwar|`C4#\}} '''anta'''- "give" → {{Tengwar|~C5$}} '''ánë''' "gave" * {{Tengwar|aDn\}} '''caw'''- "bow" → {{Tengwar|a.D5$}} '''caunë''' "bowed" * {{Tengwar|`B81E\}} '''ista'''- "know" → {{Tengwar|iG4$}} '''sintë''' "knew" * {{Tengwar|j#j#\}} '''lala'''- "laugh" → {{Tengwar|j#2$}} '''landë''' "laughed" * {{Tengwar|j$j´#\}} '''lelya'''- "go, travel" → {{Tengwar|j$2$}} '''lendë''' "went, travelled" * {{Tengwar|j^t\}} '''lom'''- "hide" → {{Tengwar|j^w$}} '''lombë''' "hid" * {{Tengwar|`H4#\}} '''onta'''- "create" → {{Tengwar|~N5$}} '''ónë''' "created" * {{Tengwar|iR61E\}} '''serta'''- "tie" → {{Tengwar|8~V7R}} '''sérë''' "tied" * {{Tengwar|1R5\}} '''ten'''- "show" → {{Tengwar|1Rs$}} '''tengë''' "showed" * {{Tengwar|yT4#}} '''vinta'''- "fade" → {{Tengwar|yT4$}} '''vintë''' "faded" Two verbs have both an irregular and a regular form: * {{Tengwar|`C1Ej1E\}} '''atalta'''- "collapse" → {{Tengwar|`C1Ej#4$ - `C1Ej1E5$}} '''atalantë'''/'''ataltanë''' "collapsed" * {{Tengwar|`N61E\}} '''orta'''- "stand, get up" → {{Tengwar|`N6Y4$ - `N61E5$}} '''orontë'''/'''ortanë''' "stood, got up"| However, the latter is said to be a difference in conjugation between intransitive "rise" and transitive/causative "raise" homonyms, thus: * {{Tengwar|`B `Vm# `N7Y4$}} '''I Elda oronte''' "The Elf arose" but {{Tengwar|`B `Vm# `N61E5$ t~C7ÎE}} '''I Elda ortane márya''' "The Elf raised his hand." The irregularities of some [[../Special Verbs|special verbs]] can be found on a separate page. ---- >> [[Neo-Quenya]] >> [[../Verbs/]] >> [[../Past Tense/]] {{BookCat}}

Neo-Quenya nouns can be declined into 9 cases and 4 numbers, so each noun has 36 forms.
Paradigms of the standard declension of nouns without stem-forms can be found on following page: [[../Declension Paradigms/]].
==Plural==
There are 2 possible endings that indicate the plural: <small>{{Tengwar|\6}}</small> -'''r''' and <small>{{Tengwar|\`B}}</small> -'''i'''.
* Words ending in <small>{{Tengwar|\`C \`B \`N \`M \`B`V}}</small> -'''a''', -'''i''', -'''o''', -'''u''', -'''ië''' get <small>{{Tengwar|\6}}</small> -'''r''': ::<small>{{Tengwar|`Cm#}}</small> '''alda''' → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cm#6}}</small> '''aldar''' (tree)
::<small>{{Tengwar|1~C7T}}</small> '''tári''' → <small>{{Tengwar|1~C7T6}}</small> '''tárir''' (queen)
::<small>{{Tengwar|`N2^}}</small> '''ondo''' → <small>{{Tengwar|`N2^6}}</small> '''ondor''' (rock)
::<small>{{Tengwar|9R7U}}</small> '''heru''' → <small>{{Tengwar|9R7U6}}</small> '''herur''' (lord)
::<small>{{Tengwar|1T`V}}</small> '''tië''' → <small>{{Tengwar|1T`V6}}</small> '''tier''' (path)
* Words ending in a consonant get -'''i''': ::<small>{{Tengwar|`C7E5}}</small> '''aran''' → <small>{{Tengwar|`C7E5%}}</small> '''arani''' (king)
::<small>{{Tengwar|t#aGj}}</small> '''macil''' → <small>{{Tengwar|t#aGj%}}</small> '''macili''' (sword)
* Words on <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''' (but not <small>{{Tengwar|\`B`V}}</small> -'''ië''') change the final <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''' into <small>{{Tengwar|\`B}}</small> -'''i''': ::<small>{{Tengwar|.D7R}}</small> '''aurë''' → <small>{{Tengwar|.D7T}}</small> '''auri''' (day)
::<small>{{Tengwar|j#,R}}</small> '''lassë''' → <small>{{Tengwar|j#,G}}</small> '''lassi''' (leaf)
Following words are irregular: * on <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''': ::<small>{{Tengwar|7Y1R+}}</small> '''rotsë''' → <small>{{Tengwar|7Y1iR6}}</small> '''rotser''' (pipe)
::<small>{{Tengwar|1Î`CyR}}</small> '''tyávë''' → <small>{{Tengwar|1Î~CyR6}}</small> '''tyáver''' (taste)
::<small>{{Tengwar|t#j°$}}</small> '''mallë''' → <small>{{Tengwar|t#j°$6}}</small> '''maller''' (street)
::<small>{{Tengwar|1ÎRj°$}}</small> '''tyellë''' → <small>{{Tengwar|1ÎRj°$6}}</small> '''tyeller''' (grade, incline)
* on <small>{{Tengwar|\`C}}</small> -'''a''' ::<small>{{Tengwar|9~B5#}}</small> '''hína''' → <small>{{Tengwar|9~B5%}}</small> '''híni''' (child)
::<small>{{Tengwar|~N5^5#}}</small> '''ónona''' → <small>{{Tengwar|~N5^5%}}</small> '''ónoni''' (twin)
==Dual== The Neo-Quenya dual is used for expressing natural pairs. So when talking about the two eyes of one person, we use the dual. But when we talk about eyes from different persons we use the ordinary plural.
So that's why we translate the dual not simply by the number two but by "a pair of": ::<small>{{Tengwar|q~V}}</small> '''pé''' "lip" → <small>{{Tengwar|q.F}}</small> '''peu''' "a pair of lips"
::<small>{{Tengwar|`Cm#}}</small> '''alda''' "tree" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cm&}}</small> '''aldu''' "a pair of trees" but ::<small>{{Tengwar|`C1;E 1~V1T}}</small> '''atta péti''' "two lips"
::<small>{{Tengwar|`C1;E `Cm#6}}</small> '''atta aldar''' "two trees"
When the dual is preceded by the [[../Article|article]] <small>{{Tengwar|`B}}</small> '''i''', it can also be translated to mean "both": ::<small>{{Tengwar|`B q.F}}</small> '''i peu''' "both lips / the two lips"
::<small>{{Tengwar|`B `Cm&}}</small> '''i aldu''' "both trees / the two trees"
'''''Formation''''': * The ending <small>{{Tengwar|\`M}}</small> -'''u''' is used when the word contains a '''d''' or '''t''' sound or when it denotes a body part: ::<small>{{Tengwar|iD7E1}}</small> '''sarat''' "sign" → <small>{{Tengwar|iD7E1U}}</small> '''saratu''' "a pair of signs"
::<small>{{Tengwar|½j#6}}</small> '''hlar''' "ear" → <small>{{Tengwar|½j#7U}}</small> '''hlaru''' "a pair of ears"
* When the noun ends on <small>{{Tengwar|}}</small> -'''a''', <small>{{Tengwar|\`B}}</small> -'''i''' or <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''' (with plural on -'''i''') use the ending <small>{{Tengwar|\1}}</small> -'''t''':
::<small>{{Tengwar|aG7ÎE}}</small> '''cirya''' "ship" → <small>{{Tengwar|aG7ÎE1}}</small> '''ciryat''' "a pair of ships"
::<small>{{Tengwar|j#,R}}</small> '''lassë''' "leaf" → <small>{{Tengwar|j#,R1}}</small> '''lasset''' "a pair of leaves"
::<small>{{Tengwar|1E5nR}}</small> '''tanwë''' "device" → <small>{{Tengwar|1E5nR1}}</small> '''tanwet''' "a pair of devices"
::<small>{{Tengwar|1~C7T}}</small> '''tári''' "queen" → <small>{{Tengwar|1~C7T1}}</small> '''tárit''' "a pair of queens"
* When these words end on <small>{{Tengwar|\`C}}</small> -'''a''' or <small>{{Tengwar|\`N}}</small> -'''o''' and are of the '''u-dual''', the <small>{{Tengwar|\`M}}</small> -'''u''' of the ending replaces these vowels:
::<small>{{Tengwar|`Cm#}}</small> '''alda''' "tree" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Cm&}}</small> '''aldu''' "a pair of trees"
::<small>{{Tengwar|1.GaY}}</small> '''tiuco''' "thigh" → <small>{{Tengwar|1.GaU}}</small> '''tiucu''' "a pair of thighs"
* When the word ends on a consonant this ending becomes <small>{{Tengwar|\`V1}}</small> -'''et''':
::<small>{{Tengwar|`C7E5}}</small> '''aran''' "king" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C7E5$1}}</small> '''aranet''' "a pair of kings"
Some words cannot take the <small>{{Tengwar|\`M}}</small> -'''u''' ending, they always take <small>{{Tengwar|\1}}</small> -'''t''': * words on <small>{{Tengwar|\`M}}</small> -'''u''':
::<small>{{Tengwar|aU2&}}</small> '''cundu''' "prince" → <small>{{Tengwar|aU2&1}}</small> '''cundut''' "a pair of princes"
* words on <small>{{Tengwar|\`B`V}}</small> -'''ië''':
::<small>{{Tengwar|1T`V}}</small> '''tië''' "path" → <small>{{Tengwar|1T`C1}}</small> '''tiet''' "a pair of paths"
* words on <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''' that form their plural on <small>{{Tengwar|\6}}</small> -'''r''':
::<small>{{Tengwar|7Y1R+}}</small> '''rotsë''' "pipe" → <small>{{Tengwar|7Y1iR1}}</small> '''rotset''' "a pair of pipes"
The word <small>{{Tengwar|yR7U}}</small> '''veru''' "married couple" is always dual.
==Partitive plural== The partitive plural replaces the words 'some' or 'a few'. The ordinary plural has the additional implied meaning 'all I am talking about'. ::<small>{{Tengwar|`B aG7ÎE6 5#6 e~C5$}}</small> '''i ciryar nar fánë''' "the ships are white" This means in fact 'all the ships I'm talking about, are white'.
But the partitive plural implies that there are also ships that have a different colour. ::<small>{{Tengwar|`B aG7ÎEj% 5#6 e~C5$}}</small> '''i ciryali nar fánë''' "some/a few ships are white"
The partitive plural can also denote something that is part of a bigger entity. ::<small>{{Tengwar|`B aG7ÎE 7Ef$ `N2^j%,R}}</small> '''i cirya rancë ondolissë''' "the ship broke upon some/a few rocks" This means that there are more rocks, but the ship didn't sail into them.
Sometimes it is used for a group that belongs to a larger group. ::<small>{{Tengwar|`Vm#j% 5#6 `Cj1R}}</small> '''eldali nar altë''' "some/a few elves are large" So we mean that there also are elves that are not so large.
But in the ordinary plural... ::<small>{{Tengwar|`Vm#6 5#6 `Cj1R}}</small> '''eldar nar altë''' "elves are large" In this sentence we mean "every elf is large".
When a noun in the partitive plural is accompanied by an adjective, the adjective has the normal plural form. ::<small>{{Tengwar|nR5Ì$ j#,Rj%}}</small> '''wenyë lasseli''' "some/a few green leaves"
But in the partitive plural the rule of the last declinable word is not applied. So the case-suffix is always applied to the noun even when there are adjectives or pronouns following behind the noun (see [[../Inflected adjectives/]]) ::<small>{{Tengwar|7Tw#j%,R5 9Cj°$}}</small> '''rimbalissen hallë''' "on some/a few high walls"
'''''Formation''''':
The basic rule is to add the suffix -'''li''' to nouns ending in a vowel: ::<small>{{Tengwar|j#,R}}</small> '''lassë''' "leaf" → <small>{{Tengwar|j#,Rj%}}</small> '''lasseli'''
::<small>{{Tengwar|aG7ÎE}}</small> '''cirya''' "ship" → <small>{{Tengwar|aG7ÎEj%}}</small> '''ciryali'''
When the noun ends on <small>{{Tengwar|\j}}</small> -'''l''', the same suffix is added. ::<small>{{Tengwar|t#aGj}}</small> '''macil''' "sword" → <small>{{Tengwar|t#aGj°%}}</small> '''macilli'''
The final letters <small>{{Tengwar|\6}}</small> -'''r''', <small>{{Tengwar|\5}}</small> -'''n''' and <small>{{Tengwar|\8}}</small> -'''s''' change into <small>{{Tengwar|\j°%}}</small> -'''lli'''. ::<small>{{Tengwar|`C1E6}}</small> '''atar''' "father" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C1Ej°%}}</small> '''atalli'''
::<small>{{Tengwar|`Vj$5}}</small> '''elen''' "star" → <small>{{Tengwar|`Vj$j°%}}</small> '''elelli'''
::<small>{{Tengwar|aY8}}</small> '''cos''' "quarrel" → <small>{{Tengwar|aYj°%}}</small> '''colli'''
Nouns ending in <small>{{Tengwar|1}}</small> '''t''', and sometimes <small>{{Tengwar|5}}</small> '''n''', get an -'''e'''- in between to make <small>{{Tengwar|\`Vj%}}</small> '''-eli'''. ::<small>{{Tengwar|iD7E1}}</small> '''sarat''' "sign" → <small>{{Tengwar|iD7E1Rj%}}</small> '''sarateli'''
Note: because of the '''-r''', '''-n''' and '''-s''' changing to '''-lli-''' rule, it is possible that two entirely different nouns have an identical partitive plural: ::<small>{{Tengwar|`C1E6}}</small> '''atar''' "father" / <small>{{Tengwar|`C1E5}}</small> '''atan''' "man" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C1Ej°%}}</small> '''atalli''' "some fathers/men"
Further distinction between identical partitive plurals could be made by adding <small>{{Tengwar|\`Vj%}}</small> -'''eli''' instead of using assimilation: ::<small>{{Tengwar|`C1E5}}</small> '''atan''' "man" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C1Ej°%}}</small> '''atalli''' → <small>{{Tengwar|`C1E5$j%}}</small> '''ataneli''' "some men"
::<small>{{Tengwar|`C1E6}}</small> '''atar''' "father" → <small>{{Tengwar|`C1Ej°%}}</small> '''atalli''' → <small>{{Tengwar|`C1E7Rj%}}</small> '''atareli''' "some fathers"
==Stem-forms== Lots of Neo-Quenya nouns have a stem-form that is used in almost all cases and number except the nominative singular. These forms can be found in the dictionary and have to be learned by heart.
Let's look at following examples: ::<small>{{Tengwar|9R5 - 9R2\}}</small> '''hen, hend-''' "eye" → <small>{{Tengwar|9R2%}}</small> '''hendi''' "eyes" → <small>{{Tengwar|9R2&}}</small> '''hendu''' "a pair of eyes"
::<small>{{Tengwar|1~Cj - 1Ej\}}</small> '''tál, tal-''' "foot" → <small>{{Tengwar|1Ej%}}</small> '''tali''' "feet" → <small>{{Tengwar|1Ej&}}</small> '''talu''' "a pair of feet"
::<small>{{Tengwar|j#t#5 - j#t5\}}</small> '''laman, lamn-''' "animal" → <small>{{Tengwar|j#t5%}}</small> '''lamni''' "animals" → <small>{{Tengwar|j#t5$1}}</small> '''lamnet''' "a pair of animals"
Note that the endings of the plural and dual are based upon the stem-form and not on the nominative singular: ::<small>{{Tengwar|qTj%5 - qTj%2\}}</small> '''pilin, pilind-''' "arrow" → <small>{{Tengwar|qTj%2%}}</small> '''pilindi''' "arrows" → <small>{{Tengwar|qTj%2&}}</small> '''pilindu''' "a pair of arrows"
A separate page is dedicated to [[../Stem-forms|an overview of stem-forms]].
===I-stems=== I-stems are nouns with a nominative singular on <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''' but that use a stem on <small>{{Tengwar|\`B}}</small> -'''i''' in all other cases. In this document they are grouped together with four other classes of related nouns:
The Neo-Quenya nouns in <small>{{Tengwar|\`V - \`B}}</small> -'''ë'''/-'''i''' can be divided into these groups: * nouns in <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''' with plural on <small>{{Tengwar|\6}}</small> -'''r''' (<small>{{Tengwar|t#j°$}}</small> '''mallë''', <small>{{Tengwar|7Y1R+}}</small> '''rotsë''', <small>{{Tengwar|1Î~CyR}}</small> '''tyávë''', <small>{{Tengwar|1ÎRj°$}}</small> '''tyellë''') * nouns in <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''' with plural on <small>{{Tengwar|\`B}}</small> -'''i''' but that keep the -'''ë''' in the singular * nouns in <small>{{Tengwar|\`V}}</small> -'''ë''' with a stem on <small>{{Tengwar|\`B}}</small> -'''i''' (real I-stems) * nouns in <small>{{Tengwar|\`B}}</small> -'''i''' * nouns in <small>{{Tengwar|\`B`V}}</small> -'''ië'''
More about these can be found on the page [[../I-stems/]].
===U-stems=== In the same way we can divide the nouns in <small>{{Tengwar|\`N - \`M}}</small> -'''o'''/-'''u''' into several groups: * nouns that keep the <small>{{Tengwar|\`N}}</small> -'''o''' in all cases * nouns with a stem on <small>{{Tengwar|\`M}}</small> -'''u''' but with a nominative singular on <small>{{Tengwar|\`N}}</small> -'''o''' (the real U-stems) * nouns that keep the <small>{{Tengwar|\`M}}</small> -'''u''' in all cases
We again refer to a separate page for further details: [[../U-stems/]].
==Cases==
Each of the cases is treated on a separate page: * [[../Nominative|Nominative case]] * [[../Genitive|Genitive case]] * [[../Possessive|Possessive case]] * [[../Dative|Dative case]] * [[../Ablative|Ablative case]] * [[../Allative|Allative case]] * [[../Locative|Locative case]] * [[../Instrumental|Instrumental case]] * [[../Respective|Respective case]]
Two special categories of nouns are: * [[../2-letter words/]] * [[../Verbal nouns/]]
----
>> [[Neo-Quenya]] >> [[../Nouns/]]
{{BookCat}}

---- >> [[Neo-Quenya]] >> [[../Nouns/]] >> [[../Declension Paradigms/]] {{BookCat}}

A number of changes in modern Quenya seem rather irregular at first sight, when we look at the evolution from Old-Elvish to Quenya however, they can be explained. Let’s look at an example: :{{Tengwar|`C7E5}} '''aran''' / {{Tengwar|`C7E5%}} '''arani''' "king" :{{Tengwar|`Vj$5}} '''elen''' / {{Tengwar|`Vj$5%}} '''eleni''' "star" :{{Tengwar|1Ej#5}} '''talan''' / {{Tengwar|1Dj#t%}} '''talami''' "floor" Why has {{Tengwar|1Ej#t%}} '''talami''' an {{Tengwar|t}} '''m''' in the plural? On the page [[../Nouns/]] we have said that {{Tengwar|1Ej#t\}} '''talam'''- was the stem of {{Tengwar|1Ej#5}} '''talan''' and we find the word as {{Tengwar|1Ej#5 ›1Ej#t\›}} '''talan (talam-)''' in the word-lists. When we look at this word in an Old-Elvish word-list we find simply {{Tengwar|1Ej#t}} '''''talam'''''. The stem-form is thus nothing else than the original Old-Elvish form of the word and the nominative-form {{Tengwar|1Ej#5}} '''talan''' is the irregular one. The reason for this irregularity is that modern Quenya no longer allows an {{Tengwar|t}} '''m''' to appear at the end of a word (see [[../Phonology/]]). So during the evolution of the language this {{Tengwar|t}} '''m''' turned in the nominative into an {{Tengwar|5}} '''n''', in the other cases it however remained unchanged. All nouns with a u-dual that belong to one of the categories on this page, use their stem-forms but are otherwise regular (we use {{Tengwar|9C7E5}} '''haran''', {{Tengwar|9C65\}} '''harn'''- "leader"): :Nom. {{Tengwar|9C65&}} '''harnu''' :Gen. {{Tengwar|9C65&`N}} '''harnuo''' :Poss. {{Tengwar|9C65&yE}} '''harnuva''' :Dat. {{Tengwar|9C65&5}} '''harnun''' :Abl. {{Tengwar|9C65&j°^}} '''harnullo''' :All. {{Tengwar|9C65&5:#}} '''harnunna''' :Loc. {{Tengwar|9C65&,F}} '''harnussë''' :Instr. {{Tengwar|9C65&5$5}} '''harnunen''' :Resp. {{Tengwar|9C65&8}} '''harnus'''. The irregular stem-forms can be found on a separate page: [[../Exceptional stems/]]. == '''d'''/'''t'''-stems == The first group of words ends in {{Tengwar|\5}} –'''n''', {{Tengwar|\6}} –'''r''' or {{Tengwar|\j}} –'''l'''. Their stem-forms are made by adding a {{Tengwar|\2\}} –'''d'''–. The second group ends in {{Tengwar|\5}} –'''n''', {{Tengwar|\6}} –'''r''' or {{Tengwar|\8}} –'''s''' and add {{Tengwar|\1}} -'''t''' to form the stem. A list of the known Quenya-words belonging to this group can be found on following page: [[../Nouns: d/t-stems]]. The adjectives on {{Tengwar|\5}} –'''n''' probably also belong to the {{Tengwar|2\}} '''d'''-stems (PE 14 pg. 77): :{{Tengwar|`B cE7T2%}} '''i hwarindi''' "the crooked (ones)" :{{Tengwar|cE7T2% 5$7T}} '''hwarindi neri''' "crooked men" When they are used as final declinable words (see [[../Inflected adjectives/]]), they get the vowels {{Tengwar|\`V\}} –'''e'''– or {{Tengwar|\`B\}} –'''i'''– between the stem and the case-ending: :{{Tengwar|9C6t# eU7T2$,F}} '''harma furindessë''' "in a concealed treasure" :{{Tengwar|`M7U6 ~M7T2$5}} '''urur úrindinen''' "with blazing hot fires" The declension of {{Tengwar|2\}} '''d'''- and {{Tengwar|1\}} '''t'''-stems is regular except in the possessive singular. In this case we use the suffix {{Tengwar|\nE}} –'''wa''' with the nominative (all nouns in this group have u-duals):

==Contracted stems== Another group of stems lose the vowel of the second syllable. So the stem-form is a contracted form of the nominative. Following nouns belong to this group: :{{Tengwar|aH7Y5}} '''coron''', {{Tengwar|aH65\}} '''corn'''- "ball" :{{Tengwar|eR7R5}} '''feren''', {{Tengwar|eR65\}} '''fern'''- "beech" :{{Tengwar|9C7E5}} '''haran''', {{Tengwar|9C65\}} '''harn'''- "leader" :{{Tengwar|9U`C5}} '''huan''', {{Tengwar|9~M5\}} '''hún'''- "dog" :{{Tengwar|j#t#5}} '''laman''', {{Tengwar|j#t5\}} '''lamn'''- "animal" :{{Tengwar|iH7Y5}} '''soron''', {{Tengwar|iH65\}} '''sorn'''- "eagle" In quite a number of cases of the singular these words use the nominative to produce these cases. =Doubled stems= There are also words in -'''t''' that have a doubled stem but they can be found on the page about [[../Exceptional stems/]]. ===doubled stems in '''ss'''=== A number of stems double their final -'''s''': :{{Tengwar|aDj#8}} '''calas''', {{Tengwar|aDj#,\}} '''calass'''- "brass" :{{Tengwar|alYt#8}} '''coimas''', {{Tengwar|alYt#,\}} '''coimass'''- "lembas" {{Tengwar|alYt#8}} '''coimas''' also has the stem-form {{Tengwar|alYt#81\}} '''coimast'''-. :{{Tengwar|`VzF8}} '''eques''', {{Tengwar|`VzF,\}} '''equess'''- "saying" :{{Tengwar|eDj#8}} '''falas''', {{Tengwar|eDj#,\}} '''falass'''- "shore, beach" :{{Tengwar|`B2%8}} '''indis''', {{Tengwar|`B2%,\}} '''indiss'''- "bride" :{{Tengwar|`B5nTj%8}} '''inwilis''', {{Tengwar|`B5nTj%,\}} '''inwiliss'''- "fairy" :{{Tengwar|`B8}} '''is''', {{Tengwar|`B,\}} '''iss'''- "light snow" :{{Tengwar|`B1T8}} '''itis''', {{Tengwar|`B1T,\}} '''itiss'''- "fly bite" :{{Tengwar|j%8}} '''lis''', {{Tengwar|j%,\}} '''liss'''- "honey" :{{Tengwar|5$8}} '''nes''', {{Tengwar|5$,\}} '''ness'''- "mead, valley, land" :{{Tengwar|5%zG8}} '''niquis''', {{Tengwar|5%zG,\}} '''niquiss'''- "frost-pattern" :{{Tengwar|5~B8}} '''nís''', {{Tengwar|5~B,\}} '''niss'''- "woman" The long {{Tengwar|~B}} '''í''' shortens before a double consonant. :{{Tengwar|lY5#j%8}} '''oinalis''', {{Tengwar|lY5#j%,\}} '''oinaliss'''- "ointment" :{{Tengwar|`Nj^8}} '''olos''', {{Tengwar|`Nj^,\}} '''oloss'''- "snow" This word also has the nominative {{Tengwar|`Nj^,R}} '''olossë'''. It should not be confused with {{Tengwar|`Nj^8}} '''olos''' "dream" which has an irregular stem-form (see [[../Exceptional stems/]]). :{{Tengwar|iG4%j%8}} '''sintilis''', {{Tengwar|iG4%j%,\}} '''sintiliss'''- "sparkling (of crystal)" :{{Tengwar|1T7T8}} '''tiris''', {{Tengwar|1T7T,\}} '''tiriss'''- "watch" :{{Tengwar|1Yj^8}} '''tolos''', {{Tengwar|1Yj^,\}} '''toloss'''- "knob, lump" :{{Tengwar|1ÎY8}} '''tyos''', {{Tengwar|1ÎY,\}} '''tyoss'''- "cough" The proper name {{Tengwar|1UjaD8}} '''Tulcas''' also belongs to this group.

The word {{Tengwar|iHj^6}} '''solor''' "surf" has stem-form {{Tengwar|iHj^,\}} '''soloss'''- and uses the same forms as these words except the possessive singular which is {{Tengwar|iHj^6nE}} '''solorwa'''. ===doubled stems in '''ll'''/'''nn'''=== Final {{Tengwar|j}} '''l''' and {{Tengwar|5}} '''n''' can also be doubled: :{{Tengwar|`Ct%j}} '''amil''', {{Tengwar|`Ct%j°\}} '''amill'''- "mother" :{{Tengwar|`C7E5$j}} '''aranel''', {{Tengwar|`C7E5$j°\}} '''aranell'''- "princess" :{{Tengwar|9Y7T5$j}} '''horinel''', {{Tengwar|9Y7T5$j°\}} '''horinell'''- "pine-needle" :{{Tengwar|t%7Tj}} '''miril''', {{Tengwar|t%7Tj°\}} '''mirill'''- "jewel" :{{Tengwar|7T`Vj}} '''riel''', {{Tengwar|7T`Vj°\}} '''riell'''- "flower-girl" :{{Tengwar|`BiGj}} '''isil''', {{Tengwar|`BiGj°\}} '''isill'''- "moon" :{{Tengwar|1Yj}} '''tol''', {{Tengwar|1Yj°\}} '''toll'''- "island" The cases of {{Tengwar|1Yj}} '''tol''' are formed with an {{Tengwar|\`N\}} –'''o'''– between stem and ending (see [[../Exceptional stems/]]). :{{Tengwar|lDj%5}} '''ailin''', {{Tengwar|lDj%5:\}} '''ailinn'''- "lake" :{{Tengwar|alDj$5}} '''cailen''', {{Tengwar|alDj$5:\}} '''cailenn'''- "throat" :{{Tengwar|aDj%w#5}} '''calimban''', {{Tengwar|aDj%w#5:\}} '''calimbann'''- "barbarian land" :{{Tengwar|aDr%5}} '''campin''', {{Tengwar|aDr%5:\}} '''campinn'''- "hips" :{{Tengwar|aHjt#5}} '''colman''', {{Tengwar|aHjt#5:\}} '''colmann'''- "summit" :{{Tengwar|`VjnR5}} '''elwen''', {{Tengwar|`VjnR5:\}} '''elwenn'''- "heart" :{{Tengwar|9Rj%5}} '''helin''', {{Tengwar|9Rj%5:\}} '''helinn'''- "pansy" :{{Tengwar|`B7T5}} '''irin''', {{Tengwar|`B7T5:\}} '''irinn'''- "town" :{{Tengwar|`B6t%5}} '''irmin''', {{Tengwar|`B6t%5:\}} '''irminn'''- "inhabited world" :{{Tengwar|j#1~MaF5}} '''latúcen''', {{Tengwar|j#1~MaF5:\}} '''latúcenn'''- "tin" :{{Tengwar|j%aG5}} '''licin''', {{Tengwar|j%aG5:\}} '''licinn'''- "horn" :{{Tengwar|t%2^5}} '''mindon''', {{Tengwar|t%2^5:\}} '''mindonn'''- "turret" :{{Tengwar|`NjnR5}} '''olwen''', {{Tengwar|`NjnR5:\}} '''olwenn'''- "branch, wand" :{{Tengwar|`N5%5}} '''onin''', {{Tengwar|`N5%5:\}} '''oninn'''- "anvil" :{{Tengwar|qRzF5}} '''pequen''', :{{Tengwar|nTj%5}} '''wilin''', {{Tengwar|nTj%5:\}} '''wilinn'''- "bird" The proper name {{Tengwar|iGjt#7Tj}} '''Silmaril''' also belongs to these words. =='''m'''-stems== As told in the introduction, the letter {{Tengwar|t}} '''m''' is no longer allowed at the end of a word and has changed into {{Tengwar|5}} '''n''' in the nominative: :{{Tengwar|`C61E5}} '''artan''', {{Tengwar|`C61Et\}} '''artam'''- "hammer" :{{Tengwar|`Bj%5}} '''ilin''', {{Tengwar|`Bj%t\}} '''ilim'''- "milk" :{{Tengwar|t$5}} '''men''', {{Tengwar|t$t\}} '''mem'''- "nose, beak" :{{Tengwar|zG5}} '''quin''', {{Tengwar|zGt\}} '''quim'''- "female" :{{Tengwar|7E5}} '''ran''', {{Tengwar|7Et\}} '''ram'''- "noise" :{{Tengwar|1Ej#5}} '''talan''', {{Tengwar|1Ej#t\}} '''talam'''- "floor" These words have exceptional locatives, instrumentals and partitive plurals:

The words with stem on {{Tengwar|\s}} -'''ng''' also behave like these words: :{{Tengwar|eDj#8nT5}} '''falaswin''', {{Tengwar|eDj#8nTs\}} '''falaswing'''- "wavecrest" :{{Tengwar|eF5}} '''fen''', {{Tengwar|eFs\}} '''feng'''- "reed" The locative is {{Tengwar|eF2$}} '''fendë''' and the partitive plural {{Tengwar|eFj°%}} '''felli''' (but the instrumental is regular: {{Tengwar|eFs$5$5}} '''fengenen'''). ==c-stems== Four words originally ended in {{Tengwar|\a}} -'''c''', and this letter is also not allowed at the end of a word: :{{Tengwar|eGj%1}} '''filit''', {{Tengwar|eGj%a\}} '''filic'''- "little bird" :{{Tengwar|5$j$1}} '''nelet''', {{Tengwar|5$ja\}} '''nelc'''- "tooth" :{{Tengwar|`N7ÎD1}} '''oryat''', {{Tengwar|`N7ÎDa\}} '''oryac'''- "badger" :{{Tengwar|zF,F1}} '''quesset''', {{Tengwar|zF,Ra\}} '''quessec'''- "pillow" They are declined as follows:
